reviewText:
-Allright, son, we made it to the shelter! Good Lord... Hey, what's that look on your face? What's bugging you?
-Dad...
-What?
-Did Mom and Mary Jane die? They ignored the siren and... bomb probably hit them...
-Well, yeah, there're probably dead. More likely. Definitely.
-Oh no...
-Hey, son, don't you dare to be upset! We've got checkers and deck of cards, so try to relax or something!
-Okay, dad... But may I ask...Why haven't you tried to save them, just like you've saved me?
-The answer is pretty obvious, son. Your sister is too fat, so instead of occuping my hands with her body, I decided to take a radio and an axe. And on the second run to the shelter with two cans of tomato soup I had only one spare hand. Too bad for your mother, rifle looked more useful than her. And less noisy.
-Uuh...
-Actually, I almost forgot to take you with me! Lucky me, you were playing in the room closest to the shelter! Hahahaha!
-Sorry for questioning your logic, dad, but why bring an axe to the shelter?
-Don't be ridiculous, son! How am I supposed to shave my beard without an axe?
-I guess you're right. Well, dad, I'm still glad we've got each other. No one knows what happened to our world after this nuke hit our town. There might be mutants out there, crazy people, bandits and other danger, we don't know about... I think we should...
-Yeah, whatever, son. Didn't mean to interrupt you, but it's afternoon and we still need a bug spray and a padlock! So get out there and find this stuff, while I discuss our future with my friend Sam The Sock Puppet.
-As you wish. dad. As you wish.

reviewText:
60 Seconds! is a combination of an action game and a text-based survival game. You play as Ted, the air raid siren has just sounded and you have 60 seconds to grab supplies and family members and get down to your fallout shelter before the bombs hit. Once in your shelter you begin a fight for survival as you ration food, try to make contact with help and venture out into the radioactive wastes.

+Great art style, really feels like it's in the 1950's
+The 60 seconds portion of the game is rather unique
+Each run has a different story but it's always interesting
+Early on in your run it's a real struggle to survive and the game provides you with a good challenge
+As well as food and water you have a number of other resources to manage which can be used in certain situations
+Some situations have rather amusing outcomes while others have outcomes which threaten the survival of the family
+The appearance of the family members changes as the longer they stay in the bunker and appearances also change when they become ill or similar
+Most situations can be approached in different ways, for example if there's a dark, unexplored room you can use a flashlight to see what's in there or use your gun to scare off possible hostiles
+If, like me, you aren't so keen on the 60 seconds part you can start from the bunker and you'll be given a random selection of resources and family members making it feel like a rogue-like
+The writing, until it gets repetitive, is great
+Great humour
+Great tutorial

-The controls for the 60 seconds in the house aren't great, they're very insensitive and sometimes the control for picking up an item doesn't work even when you're standing next to it which is very frustrating
-After around Day 60 it just becomes a case of clicking through the text to get to the next day without doing anything
-Sometimes the game presents you with situations you can't actually do due to you not having the right item which is also quite frustrating
-The writing gets repetitive quite quickly, in my first run I got to Day 78 (before my save got corrupted) and I saw some situations four or five times

Verdict:
Worth Purchasing (7.5/10)

An interesting idea combined with great text-based survival with a great art style, interesting stories, good humour and good writing.

El K.

reviewText:
Gone in 60 Seconds

There’s not a lot you can do in 60 seconds.
Boil a kettle, nuke something in the microwave, maybe have a wee, of course if you’re Nicolas Cage then could hot wire a car, but that’s Hollywood for you.
But what if your future and that of your family depended on the decisions you made over one short pressure filled minute?


Busy Doing Nothing

Imagine a situation where you’re sitting at home.
Glancing around you can see all sorts of junk begging to be tidied away; maybe if you leave it long enough your wife and kids (who are around the house somewhere) might get around to doing it.
As you idly wonder who left a crate of bottled water in the corner of the living room a screeching noise shatters the silence.

You’re filled with dread as you realise that it’s the sound of the early warning system wailing outside.
We knew politicians would be the death of us and it seems that day has finally come.
The bombers must already be on their way, carrying their payloads of nuclear Armageddon,
The world is about to end...


Don’t Worry, Be Happy

... But don’t worry, you’ve prepared, unlike most of the other saps who are about to take a crash course in nuclear fission you had the foresight to install a nuclear bunker under your house!
You smile smugly to yourself, all that time playing fallout was well spent after all and in a few seconds you’ll be sitting safely in your cosy vault as the world above you turns into a radioactive wasteland.


Tick Tock

Moving for the shelter your eyes again drift to the crate of bottled water and an awful realisation washes all traces of smugness away.
You might have had the foresight to build a fallout shelter, but you never did get around to filling it with supplies did you?
Cursing your laziness you look desperately around the room, what items are you going to need in your shelter?
Food, Water, maybe the wife and kids to keep you company?
The alarms are still wailing outside, how much warning do they give you?
60 seconds?
Dashing towards the bottled water you trip over a can of soup, stumble and crash into a chair, if only your house wasn’t in such a mess!
Which room are the kids in anyway?
... tick... tock...


Pre-Apocalypse

This is the premise behind the first part “60 Seconds” a unique little survival title developed by Robot Gentleman Studios.
I say the first part, because “60 Seconds” is split into two very distinct yet connected games.
The first part of the game is a quick and frantic “treasure hunt” around your house.
You’ll control your character as he runs and stumbles through the various rooms searching for supplies to take down into the bunker.
You’re given a few short seconds to explore your surroundings before the sirens blare and the countdown begins, this time is vital to quickly scan around the layout of your house and look for the locations of useful items. (This changes every time you play!)


Supermarket Sweep

Before you’ve had chance to complete your stock take the countdown will begin, it’s time to start grabbing those supplies and dropping them down the hatch into your vault.
It’s not as simple as grabbing everything in one go either, you can only carry so much at a time,  this leads to a frantic dash through the various rooms with armfuls of tinned food or bottled water.
This is 60 seconds of sandbox physics mayhem.

Furniture will go flying, objects will get in your way and you’ll be looking for one thing and get distracted by something else.
A radio might be useful to keep in touch with the outside world, maybe a good book would help stave off the boredom, there must be a first aid kit somewhere, etc.
These are the thoughts that will go through your head as you crash passed tables and fall over chairs in the rush.
It’s an ultra intense supermarket sweep and it’s as fun as it is frustrating!


Take Shelter

This is just the beginning, after diving into the bunker yourself, you’ll get to experience vault life and ration out those precious supplies to prolong your existence (and that of your family if you got around to saving them) for as long as possible.

Of course, if you got distracted by something shiny and didn’t make it into the shelter in time then you’ll be dead and need to start a new game, so let’s assume you did make it, because it’s in the shelter that the real fun starts.


Post-Apocalypse

The game changes pace in the shelter and becomes a short tongue in cheek survival adventure.
You’ll spend the remainder of the game looking at a static screen of yourself and any rescued family members sitting in the vault along with whatever supplies you managed to scavenge.

Each day this screen will be updated to reflect any changes in your little vault, including the ever dwindling supplies sitting on the shelf behind you.
Your food and water will almost certainly require rationing if you’re to last until help arrives, keep someone hungry or thirsty for too long though and they’ll get sick and die.

Other items you threw into the shelter could well prove useful too, you see, strange things happen when you’re cooped up in a vault.
A board game might be enough to stave off madness and a can of bug spray might be handy if you don’t want to share your bunker with some new scuttling friends.


Dear Diary

Like a post apocalyptic Adrian Mole, you keep a diary in the vault, but there’s more to write about than the dwindling water supplies.
Vault life is more eventful than you might think, random events happen every day and it’s these events that drive the narrative forward.
Each day you will go through food and water rationing, deciding who (if anyone) gets something to eat or drink that day.You’ll then read through the vault diary,
it’ll cover the health and moods of your surviving family members and report on any interesting events that occurred that day.


Kevin Costner or Mad Max?

Mutants, bandits, a nice game of scrabble, anything could happen as you wait out the apocalypse and most of these events will require you to make a decision which will impact the narrative as the days progress.

There’s a banging on the vault door, It could be a post apocalyptic mailman delivering some goodies, or it could just as likely be a gang of bandits fresh from the set of Mad Max, do you answer it? Well that’s up to you.


Valued in the Vault

The outcome of many of these events will depend on the salvaged items from the first part of the game.
If a radioactive bug bites a family member, you’d better hope you bought a first aid kit with you or the consequences might prove surprising.

Your first play through will give you an idea of the importance of the various items you ignored whilst foraging for cans of soup to bring down into the vault.
This game will quickly teach you that no matter how innocuous an item seems, it could well prove useful in the vault.


Keep Taking the Tablets

60 Seconds is a refreshing and quirky little game but It definitely feels like a tablet conversion.
It’s quick to play and immediately addictive which is great, unfortunately, like most mobile gaming ports, it can feel a little shallow and become repetitive pretty quickly.
Having said that, it’s priced to reflect this short term appeal and there is no denying the hours of entertainment you’ll get out of playing it.

60 seconds isn’t looking for a relationship, it’s looking for a fling.
Its fun whilst it lasts, you’re going to enjoy it but you probably won’t remember it in the morning.
It’s the one night stand of post apocalyptic gaming!


If you enjoyed this review you can find the full version and many others HERE[www.review-well.com]

reviewText:
I have played this game more than all the reviewers listed on the front store page combined at this writing.

I give this game a thumbs sideways -- theming and setting are good, gameplay is not.

The majority of gameplay consists of quickly paging past daily status updates of who hungry or thirsty, and assigning rations accordingly.   With only rare exceptions, it is a foregone conclusion how to assign rations, it usually doesn't feel like you are actually making a decision that you might have done differently to result in a different outcome.  So most of what you are doing in this game is a kind of mindless make-work to see the next random result.

You might have a person who is sick or wounded -- but usually you will not have a medikit available to do anything about it, and if you do you will almost certainly use it right away.  Again, it's almost as if there is no true decision to be made that will change the result.

Perhaps once a week you might send the healthiest out to explore and find supplies.  You only choose who to send, not where they go or what they focus on finding.  It's random where they go and what they bring back.  If you need a medikit or radio you can't focus on finding one, you just have to hope you get the random event result that makes it happen.  This can be frustrating when you have someone dying of starvation or disease as your explorer comes back with a discovered flashlight.

Also once a week you might have a decision of consequence -- for at least half of these you quickly figure out which choice is best and it no longer feels like a real decision in future attempts.

There is a fatigue system which can affect your characters, but there is nothing the player can do to avoid fatigue or mitigate it other than hoping for different random results.  So how interesting is it to read status reports about how fatigued each character is when you have no control over it whatsoever?   You can't assign them rest, and according to the devs exploring and rations  have no effect on it.

Ultimately, the game feels like a random result generator.
Some of the events and outcomes are interesting and amusing enough that you want to play more to see more of them.
And you do sometimes learn over time which decisions are better for certain events.

But for the most part the game doesn't feel like one where you have significant effect over the outcome.

Maybe that's actually realistic in an odd way, when you've got a family in a bomb shelter and starving neighbors, there is an awful lot that is out of your control.

It doesn't make for compelling gameplay however.

The devs promise to add a lot more event content in the future.
I hope as the game evolves the players feel like they have more of an impact on the outcome.

reviewText:
60 Seconds left me wanting more. I wanted more of its quirky, charming, art style and music. I wanted more of its scavenging mechanics. I wanted more crazy radiation filled events. From turning into a giant cockroach being, to dealing with raiders. 60 Seconds captures the dark humor of living in a post apocalyptic world.
The game is broken up into two parts. The first being a randomly generated house scene where items you need are scattered around the house. You collect much needed supplies, family, and other items in the limited time of sixty seconds. After you hop into the bomb shelter this part of the game is done and gone. While this works well and makes playthroughs unique. Offering replay as you never know what your going to get. However I felt this area could've been explored more. Especially when you get to the bunker. Which brings you to second part of the game. The survival aspects are fun to manage. Keeping track of what food and water is left and the random events that occur. Watching your characters slowly degrade from the bright chipper 1950's family. Into some horrible nightmare version of themselves. You will choose what to use and who to send out for more supplies. While the logbook is an enjoyable read. I would've liked to seen the outside world. Actually scavenged for the food and water that I so desperately needed. See the house from beginning in its new state. This is where I feel 60 Seconds missed a great chance. Adding more of its humor and quirky art style and raising the stakes to put your fate in your own hands.

In spite of this, 60 Seconds is a fun bite sized game. Each play session can last anywhere from 20 to 40 minutes and It never over stays its welcome. I just hope there is enough random events and outcomes to keep me in the bunker.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/V9jAr1R-MeI
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

reviewText:
This game is fun!

I guess, once the apocalypse comes in form of an atomic bomb, I'm gonna die. At least if the real apocalypse is anything like this game. I probably won't be saving my family once the bomb hits, 'cause all they do is eat my soup and drink my water. Yes, my soup and my water. It's mine 'cause I was the one that grabbed it before we ran to the bunker.

If my lovely wife or children would have grabbed anything useful it could be theirs, but they didn't so it's mine. Mine, mine, mine.
Don't worry guys, I'm not gonna let you starve or die of dehydration, now that I've rescued you and taken you with me into the bunker. All I'm saying is, that I'm sharing my soup and my water with you, so the least you can do is stop complaining how you're tired of eating soup and would prefer apple juice to water. I mean, guess what? I'd prefer being in a shelter with someone who doesn't try to poison me with bug spray, while calling it medicine.

Also, don't open the bunker for everyone that knocks. Yes, there may be nice guys out there who need our help, but if those nice guys were also smart guys, they would hide out inside their own bunker, with their own soup and water and wouldn't try to get mine.

Good thing I don't have a wife or kids, otherwise I'd spend the 60 seconds I have to grab stuff to take with me into the bunker, contemplating wether to save them or grab a gas mask or maybe the flashlight. How do you weight the importance of little Timmy versus the usefulness of a functioning radio? Ok, not fair for little Timmy. I'll definitely grab the radio. But come on Timmy, you have two healthy legs, there are sirens going off, just get yourself into the bunker. It's not like I'd throw you out, if you go into it by yourself. Sending you on a mission to grab some supplies is not throwing you out, little Timmy. You have a fair chance of making it back to the bunker alive. At least usually a better chance than your sister Mary Jane. She's a bit unlucky.

Good thing Dolores doesn't complain when one of her kids die. It's a little weird though... Shouldn't she at least feel something when we're told that little Mary Jane isn't coming back to the bunker, 'cause the raiders captured her? All she ever does is tell me how she wants something to eat or if I can spare some water for her. Come on, Dolores. Your kid just got captured by savages and you don't feel anything? Really? Nothing? This situation really makes me wonder what I saw in you all those years ago. Why did we get married? Also, am I really little Timmy's father? Really? He looks nothing like me.
If we ever make it out of this alive Dolores, I think we need to have a long conversation.

reviewText:
GeneralIn 60 Seconds! you're Ted in a post-apocalyptic world. You have 60 seconds to gather as many supplies as possible (that includes your family, maybe?) and hurry down to the fallout shelter! There are different game modes too - Anyway: Once in the shelter and depending on what items you looted beforehand, you'll have to ration food and water throughout the occupants in the fallout shelter (be wise). You can interact with certain items that you looted, for example: the radio. Turn the radio on to hear if it is safe or not to come out. If that doesn't sound interesting, you can make Ted or his family go out and scavenge. Scavenging can be dangerous but sometimes strategic if you're lucky.

During your shelter time, some random events will occur that can affect the outcome of your survival. These events will make you choose to answer knocks on the door, for example. You can never know what will happen until you're put in the situation.

My Opinion60 Seconds! is an interesting game, and different I may add. During the 60 seconds you have to throw everything down the shelter is nerve wracking, because you are always looking at the timer. They give you enough time to gather as many things as possible - some may probably disagree. It is quite the challenge. It's pretty hilarious that you can choose to bring your family or not. Not sure how it will play out if you don't bring any of them.

There's a lot of reading involved when you're in the fallout shelter. You can skim through paragraphs after paragraphs of text, but sometimes when you need to make a strategic decision, that may come at a price. I find it easier to skip the nonsense and read the important parts. I guess if the reading portion was a big more exciting to read it wouldn't be so bad; however, I'm not a reader like most people unless it is a game changer. Reading is pretty important around when certain events appear or when someone is back from scavenging.

The UI is very simple and easy to work with, AND the tutorial was just awesome. However, during the tutorial I couldn't skip on forward after the military guy (forgot his name) said, Use the grab button to skip". The grab button is Left Mouse Button since that's what Ted grabs items with. Perhaps I read it wrong? Nonetheless
date:
I prevailed!

I survived 32 days only because Ted died of thirst and my family died 2 days before.

OverallI'm enjoying this game. I recommend it to anyone that enjoy these types of games
recommended: and I hope my review can help you decide whether to buy 60 Seconds! or not.\n\nRating: 8/10"

reviewText:
You are Ted: loving husband, father of two. You lead a lovely, peaceful life with your family until the nuclear apocalypse strikes. Now, you have 60 Seconds to decide what’s important enough to bring into the shelter with you… and survive as long as possible.

60 Seconds is not quite what I expected it to be, though in all honesty I’m not sure entirely what I was expecting of the game, but it has its charm still.
It is, in its core, a survival text adventure with some mild dark comedy thrown in. Yes, there’s a part that’s kind of action-y (the initial 60 seconds of it), but it’s played for such small amount of time it’s hardly noticeable, even if the contents are quite relevant to the development of the story.

Let’s split it up.

Entering the game you’re presented with the options (not counting the tutorial): A regular game, which includes the action part and the survival part; a scavenging game (which includes just the action/scavenging part) and the survival part (which is survival/text adventure, mostly, with randomly generated resources).
Each game play style has three modes: easy, medium and hard. I rather enjoyed that they would give us the freedom to choose which part we liked best to play, rather than force us to do both play styles in one go.

On the action/scavenging part of the game, you have 60 seconds to gather as many items/resources as you can, toss them in your shelter, and enter it yourself. You find all this in your house: your house is randomly generated with each new game, so that the items and rooms are never in the same place. The items you can get range from food and water, to your family, radio, axe, gun, gas mask and other survival items. At the end of the 60 seconds, you must be within a certain area near the shelter, or risk not surviving the apocalypse yourself. To make matters more complex, you have only four slots, and some items take up two slots, so you’ll have to make several trips to the shelter to get everything there.

The graphics on this part of the game are 3D cartoony; they feel kind of awkward to me, and so do the controls. You move with wasd and turn with the mouse, but turning takes too long. You grab the items with a mouse click, but in order to grab it you have to be facing it almost perfectly (the white outline will turn red) and as I’ve just stated, turning is really friggin’ hard, making the whole 60 seconds section super frustrating. Still wanting to up the complexity of the controls, furniture will be in your way, which means you can bump into it and drag it along, slowing you down. This would, again, be much less annoying if you could turn without having to move your mouse in 500 circles per quarter of a turn.

Thus, a section of the game that could have been quite fun was instead rendered quite annoying and frustrating (in case the first 50 times I said it was annoying and frustrating wasn’t understood… )

Once the 60 seconds are up, you move on to the survival part.

Congratulations! You’ve survived the bomb! But now you must survive until you are rescued. This is the part of the game I enjoyed the most, even if some of the texts and outcomes became both a bit repetitive and predictable.

You switch from the 3D cartoony graphics to 2D cartoony graphics. I wasn’t overly fond of the art style at first, but it grew on me, and now it just seems to fit the mood of the game quite well.
On this screen you will be presented with however many survivors and resources you threw into the shelter.
Each day you will go through the same motions: you open up the notebook, and it will tell you a little story, what’s going on with the family, what’s needed, etc… Each day you can ration food and water to them (or not). Every so often you will get story prompts: send someone to the surface, fix this, kill that, solve a problem, etc… and you may not always be able to do them all, depending on if you have the item needed for it or not.

The graphics, though mostly still, are quite dynamic. You see the family change as days go on and things happen: they will look different when sick or hurt, when hungry or crazy, they will grow beards, get dirty, etc…

For the most I enjoyed this part, but it was a bit bothersome that no adults in the bunker meant you instantly died. I could understand it if only the youngest boy was the only one to have survived, but I’m fairly sure the teenage girl is capable of at the very least open a can of soup/bottle of water, so I think it’s rather unfair that if she’s left alone she ‘dies’ the very next day. I should at the very least be allowed to play her until she actually truly dies too or runs out of resources or whatever.

60 Seconds has some very amusing parts when it comes to the text, if rather dark in nature, but it can also be quite frustrating to play in the scavenging part. I feel like the problems turning and grabbing things should be considered more as a bug than as something they should’ve done to make the 60 seconds more difficult, and I hope they will consider fixing it in the future. (Yes, I know, the bug report sticky says it’s fixed, but it’s still too slow for me even after having gone to the settings).

I also hope they will add more endings as even in a short play through some of the events and endings repeated. Aside from that, 60 seconds can be quite an enjoyable game, particularly as you can choose to replay whichever section you have a preference for without having to forcibly do the other. It won’t be amazing, and it’s probably not worth quite the full price (maybe pricing it $5 would be better than $10), but it’s not a bad game at all.

reviewText:
First game after tutorial
I gather many supplies
Get all of my family members into the shelter
I run into kitchen to get a few more supplies
turn around and a hat rack is blocking my way
get trapped in the kitchen and die by the nuclear bomb

And now for the actually review
60 Seconds is game where you are the father of a nice loving family in the 1950's, whose lives are about to be changed forever.  In this game you have 60 seconds to gather as many resources as you can to take to your shelter.(Food,water, weapons, and other supplies) And after that you try to survive in the shelter in till you die or get rescued. And while you're in the shelter various scenarios occur that affect your family's lives, health, and thoughts. And not only that, but there is a journal kept that explains everything going on in a funny timely manner.

Negatives:
And there are some negatives of this great game:
-Low replayability- Although the game is fun, you can't really play the game for more than a hour without getting bored, so it's better if you play the game every other day.
-Events and scenarios tend to be similar every time you play- Each game I play I experience similar events, The famous Earth Quake" is one that I almost always witness when I play the game
date:
which always results in an object getting broken. Unless that is supposed to occur.
-Sickness- Sickness is a huge factor in the game for me. Every time a family member gets sick they almost have no chance of living unless they get cured by a medkit.

Although the game has some negative problems with it
recommended: it is a new game that was just released a few days ago and the developer is actually concerned with what the players are complaining about. With promises about big updates in the future fixing the game and adding more. So I rate this game 8/10 cans of Tomato Soup.\n"

reviewText:
This is a creative concept but the game needs a little bit more work.  A single playing of this game will last about an hour or  so.  The funnest part is the first 2 minutes(running around the house to grab stuff), the other 58 minutes is spent flipping through pages basically just reading text and answering questions.  This part drags a bit.  Especially since I can't seem to get rescued in under 60 days in the bunker.

The game would be loads better if there were some mini games interspersed through the bunker stage.  For example, when someone leaves to go get food, they could use the same engine as the beginning and you control your character running around the wasteland to find items to bring back while avoiding hazards.  If they could address this portion of the game it would be much more enjoyable.  Or maybe when the person arrives to gamble for water, you actually play cards(if even just choosing whether to fold or bet).  One more idea:  when the bugs come in you play a little mini game to smash them with whatever tools you have(varying in effectiveness).

I realize this game is only $10 and am rating it accordingly.  I would give it 3 out of 5 stars but since I can only recommend yes or no, Im going with no.  In its current state there are better games out there to spend $10 on.

reviewText:
I wish there was a neutral option, but since there isn't, I recommend it with hesitation.  Buy this game on sale.  I like it as a game to play for a few minutes every now and then, but it's still not worth $10 unless they start updating and adding more items and scenarios regularly.

The scavenging part of the game is only minor, thankfully (and, like the name implies, only for a minute.)  The controls are wonky, you can be standing with your face on an item and not be able to pick it up, and your family is completely useless and wastes a significant portion of your time to get their stupid asses into the shelter.

Once you finish (or mercifully skip) that, the game is fun if repetitive.  If you somehow manage to be good at scavenging, it becomes even more repetitive once you learn what the important items are and go straight for those.  For that reason, I usually skip right to the survival" mode

reviewText:
*****EDIT SEPT 14, 2015
I want to say upfront that I love supporting independent gaming studios – I always want to root for the little guy, and sometimes the gems they produce are the greatest products ever made.

With that said, there is a disturbing trend which has manifested within the (saturated) game development community:  the dreaded supporting of Pre-release games -- whether it be through a public fundraising such as Kickstarter or through a program like Steam Greenlight.
“60 Seconds!,” and its developer Gentleman Robot, appear to be the latest victims (or offenders depending on your POV) of this trend.

As a full disclaimer, I have not closely followed the development of this game since its early production Greenlight days, and was only made aware of its history when @beren (an apparent developer of the 60 Seconds!) posted in the comments section of my review.  According to Beren, “60 Seconds! is released on the promise that all future DLC would be free and forthcoming.”

However, I did not purchase this game in a “pre-release” state; I purchased it in an advertised “complete” state, for $10.00.  I (and many others) have learned my lesson the hard way, by supporting a game in a pre-release state, only to have the game rushed and “released complete” -- i.e. unfulfilled, buggy, unplayable, etc. etc.  The mantra from the devs is then “DLC, DLC, DLC ….”
Usually after months, if not longer, the game is somewhat patched, in a semi-stable/semi-playable state … and then basically abandoned by the developers, who have moved onto a new project, leaving the consumers/gamers burned and without an enjoyable game.  In essence, it’s a cash grab for a bait ‘n switch product, and it happens a HUGE majority of the time when dealing with independent studios.

So at Beren’s suggestion of re-playing the game with its new DLC, I gave the game a second-chance and disregarded the fact that I should have already had a completed game to play, as opposed to waiting around for DLC.  I can report, that after playing the game with the new DLC, I feel as though I have been put through the ringer of one of the most elaborate troll-jokes ever.

I was expecting the DLC to have added any type of actual gameplay or substantial level building to the almost non-existent, present content.  It does not.  From what I can tell, it has added a whopping two items (a briefcase and padlock), maybe an added music track and a few minor decision branches.

As it stands now, with added DLC, the game consists of a 60-second, item collection mini-game and then one screen with very basic, almost not existent flash animation.  Let me repeat: $10.00 game with a 60-second mini-game and one flash animation screen.

They devs obviously worked harder on the intro (which is by far the most interesting part of this “game”), because that’s the new industry norm: Make a great demo for your game idea, shop that idea around at conventions and on Steam, sell a shell of that game idea at top dollar and finally hope to produce enough DLC to satisfy the contract before moving onto the next project.

With what has been produced and released to-date, at absolute best, this is a mobile game which should be sold as an app for $0.99.  I can see it as a silly little time-waster on your phone or something, but it has no business being released for the PC.

60 Seconds! Is a great idea for a game.  The devs have caught the feel, mood, dark humor and music which perfectly captures 1950 Cold War.  They’ve sold this package for $10.00 ….
Now where’s the actual game?

This is an open forum, and I really encourage an open dialogue with the devs on these points listed.  I am genuinely interested in coming to some type of happy medium on these concerns – perhaps I’m missing something?  I’m certainly willing to listen and discuss. **********



**EDIT SEPT 9th 2015**
********Well -- Free DLC appears to be on it's way in a matter of days.  Free DLC now, and free future DLC ... as expressed by the devs themselves (see comments section below).  I've said numerous times this game has promise, so I am hopeful it will be good.  So while a thumbs down ATM, maybe my opinion will change with the DLC.  Will update when DLC is avaiable. **********

*******************************************************************************************************************
*****************************    ORIGINAL REVIEW SEPT. 7th, 2015 **************************

reviewText:
This isn't an action game. Sure, the first minute is fast-paced chaos, but over the course of the following 30 or so minutes it reveals itself as a game where a story slowly unfolds - the story of your (probable) death.

Gameplay video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zF4iuWXGsFg

Most of that story takes place on one static screen - you do a lot of reading and make life & death decisions that get surprisingly involving as the tension mounts. So you need to take your time and let yourself be absorbed by the story, rather than mashing buttons to get to the end.

Note also that each playthrough is different because the daily events/decisions are randomised:

Yay

reviewText: I'll admit, this isn't the greatest game- it isn't something I'm gonna get addicted to, but for 8 dollars, it's a pretty fun game to keep me entertained for a while! I've played a number of times, and I can never seem to survive- my longest time alive was 52 days. And one of the coolest things is that I'm actually feeling nervous and stressful (in a good way) since every decision could potential mean life or death. Should I ration out the last bit of food or wait a turn? Should I open the door to see what the mysterious knocking is about? Should I send out poor Timmy to scavenge even though he's sick? Overall, this is a pretty fun and whimsical survival game that I would recommend!

This game is a lot of fun! It may not have the most replay value in the World, but it's still a fun survival/adventure game. The art style and music are great. Both fit the 1950s time-line well. I really enjoy the humor in the game, as well. It makes the story more fun to follow.

reviewText:
~Meadow's Review~
Having played several playthroughs I must say I'm very impressed at the 60 second time limit into scavenging goods from 3D and then continue playing the game 2D. Other similar games with a scavenge/survival phase do not have an actual mechanic like this or a different form of it. Personally speaking, I seriously like how you can decide what to take in that very 60 seconds which will determine failure or not.

So the game has four modes of plays, the first one being the Tutorial mode which will walk you through the simple necessities for survival in a nuclear shelter as well as enable you to explore with plenty of time in your home. Followed by the Apocalypse mode which combines scavenging as well as survival. Then Scavenge mode in which you can practice more with scavenging goods. Does not include survival mode however. And lastly Survival mode, which skips the scavenging part of the game and randomizes what and whom you brought with you to the shelter. At all times must one adult remain in the shelter lest it be taken by hostile forces.

You're Ted, the main family person of the game. You cannot choose another player, I hope the developers do consider being able to choose the other adult, Dolores or add more characters to play or find. He can hold up to 4 hands" worth of goods or people. His family first:

Dolores
recommended: Mary Jane 3 hands. I assume this is because of her tuba
hoursPlayed: which I don't see back in the shelter. And his son
voteText: Timmy
helpfulPercent: 2 hands. Remember
votesHelpful: you do not need to take all of them with you
votesTotal:
since more people will mean more mouths to feed and drink. But more options to choose from going out to scavenge.

Followed by the goods:
Cans of soup. 1 hand per can. This is the only thing you can eat. Yes
votesFunny:
we're running in a tomato economy here!
Bottles of water. 1 hand per bottle. This is also the only thing you can drink!
Both of the above 1 can/1 bottle = 4 uses.

Medical kit. 2 hands. Used to combat unable to sleep
commentsCount:
healing up any kind of injury or sickness. One use only in most events.
Gas Mask. 1 hand. With this the chance of getting ill outside from radiation is greatly reduced.
Ammunition. 1 hand. Seems to have some special events tied with it.
Checker board. 1 hand. Seems to combat boredom.
Cards. 1 hand. Same as above. Also useful in gambling.
Map. 1 hand. Quite useful for locating objectives in special events.
Radio. 1 hand. With this you can hear what the army is planning as well as other special events. Very useful.
Flashlight. 1 hand. You can shine in the dark with this in some events.
Boy's Scout Book. 1 hand. Can be used to learn how to effectively repair things in events as well as giving out hints when clicked.
Axe. 2 hands. Can be great as multi-purpose tool including combat situations.
Rifle. 2 hands. Great for self defense!

Remember

you only have 60 seconds. with different difficulty modes you have more time to scout your home before being able to ultimately grab things you think you need.

+ And in turn

reviewText:
A simple enough concept.  You gather supplies then try to last as long as possible in your bunker, rationning food, water and taking decisions on random events.

Pros :
-Lots of humor
-Addictive
-You can select to skip the supply gathering phase if you want
-Very very 50's
-Devs quick to answer questions and are open about their work

Cons :
-Had to turn off the music after a bit
-More random events would be nice (but they're working on a free DLC to add more so I won't hold it against them)
-Kind of wish you could give supply goals.  It's frustrating when people die of thirst and your supply run comes back with a scout handbook.

Recommended, fun and fairly priced.

reviewText:
One-Sentence SummaryUnique and amusing at first glance, this game wears out its welcome after the same text events are recycled over and over during the many replays it requires to learn how to give yourself the best odds of beating the oft-unforgiving RNG.

Pros+ Cohesive atomic-era visual design and game concept
+ Plenty of good and (slightly) morbid humor
+ Captures the essence of life in a bunker (or so I would imagine)

Cons- Events repeat ad nauseam
- Repeated runs are necessary to learn how to win... but...
- too repetitious / slow / tedious to enjoy the process of getting good enough to win
- Less about strategy, more about memorizing story fork outcomes & probabilities
- Choices often lack reliable feedback; ie. how much luck influenced the outcome

Final ThoughtsI was pretty excited to try this game out, as I have a (probably) strange fascination with the idea of apocalytpic bunker life.  Conceptually and visually it looks pretty great, but the way it plays out gets extremeley repetitive and tedious to do continuous runs, re-reading the same text over and over (but randomly sequenced) and hoping that the options you choose lead to the desired outcome.  Unfortunately, the game is also much less about strategic survival choices and often the RNG will condemn you down a path of death even when you choose the best or correct" options.  Alas
date: the game design does not do a good enough job of creating frustration-free variation and the illusion of player control with non-linearity; it ends up feeling like you're just choosing some fork on a tree diagram and hoping the fork RNG doesn't lead to an unrecoverable dead-end."

reviewText:
Pro's:The game is light weight with relatively fast&fun game play. The game is very well put together, it has great humor and many references to the Fallout universe an some other pop culture references.

Cons: The controls in the opening part where you scavenge supplies are a bit junk; slow clicking speed; annoying hit boxes on objects, granted it's only 60-80 seconds long. Though the humor and game play is fun, it gets stale after about 2-3 hours of game play. There isn't much in the way of randomness other then events, and you pretty much can encounter every game play joke,choice or event within one play through. It feels like an IOS game as the entirety of the games controls is just clicking.*

Price: Even on sale for 5$ again it feels like a $1.99 IOS game and should be priced as such*.

Final thoughts: Its a good game, just its not on the right platform. If the prices was lowered and the developer and steam added mobile gaming support though the steam app in the future this title would out class a lot of IOS games and would be worth the pick up.

reviewText:
TL;DR: The game is fun for 20 minutes and then you've seen everything.  Not worth the high price tag


The game is split into 2 parts.  The first part lasts 60 seconds where you run around the house and try to grab supplies for your bunker.  The second half of the game has you surviving in your shelter.

The problem with the second part, which takes up most of the game, is that it's very passive.  It's not like you actually do anything, you just react or select options in scenarios based on what items you were able to gather.  For instance, if you picked up a deck of cards, you might be presented with the option to... play cards.

An entire game lasts about 15 minutes and there is virtually no replayability because there is no strategy involved.  Just clicking through a number of pre-generated scenarios.

If this game had been $1.99 on the app store, I would have had no regrets.  However for the price it's listed at, it's just not enough game for the dollar.

reviewText: Honestly I bought this game because it was on sale at the time and I was feeling burnt out from most of my other games at the time, however I was pleasently suprised by the amount of content and real fun this game had to offer. The first time I played it I found it to be incredibly fun for a $10 indie title. It has a variety of different gamemodes and playstyles to suit your preferance. I believe for what the game is, it has a perfect balance of an initial mad dash for loot followed by a quest for wasteland surivial that is not in your favor. Some people will argue that the game is far too text based and that it is missing some intense combat and looting through your characters eyes, but I know that developers made the right decision by limiting movement and action to the beginning. The random events and abundance of choices are some of things that make the gameplay feel very rewarding and making a trumph all the more worth it due to your small change of sucess in amlost every scenario. One of the main reasons I bought this game is that unlike amost every single new game for sale on steam today, this game is not in early access and never was in early access. It is much more rewarding to play a game that is not lacking content as most games do these days. Hats off to the devs for packing so much fun into a seemingly small game. Your possiblities are endless in your quest for survival in the wastleland and in your humble bunker alike. Always remeber, stock up on tomato soup and water before it's too late.

reviewText: Survive as a family or as a couple, but surviving alone isn't an option. Insanity is real and if Ted goes insane, game over, he'll run away. A challenging survival game based in the nuclear fallout that could've happened during WWII. You get only 1 minute to gather everything you can, so be sure to note where things are prior to that one minute. If you don't gather enough or save too many people, you will run out of supplies very quickly in the shelter. Keep sicknesses in check or it will kill your people, and many other things provide challenges based on RNG. The overall feel to the game is cartoonish with tongue and cheek comedy, and it has some interesting easter eggs in it. I'd give it a 7/10 , it's fun and worth a playthrough at least once! Different outcome everytime almost gurranteed.

reviewText:
The idea is cute; that nuclear war sirens go off, and give you 60 seconds to run around your house collecting family members/supplies to survive on for lord-knows-how-long, but the game is poorly executed, and disappointing.  The previews are misleading, the gameplay isn't anything like they show.  The 3D part of the game, where you run around for a minute, grabbing supplies, has poor controls, poor hit detection for grabbing things (which is REALLY important!), needless slowdowns, and delays in picking up items after clicking them... very frustrating.  Repetitive music, and all of maybe 3 different sounds for interacting with your environment make the game sound like either a high school intro to programming class assignment, or a very, very unfinished and undeveloped game that barely qualifies as a beta build.

The gameplay is kinda of like full metal jacket (movie), only terrible, and feels like 2 seperate, unrelated games.  The first minute of the game is spent frantically and frustratingly trying to grab useful supplies, with hints from a radio on what you'll probably need, which isn't fun at all.  Poor controls/hit detection aside, this task isn't remotely entertaining... running between rooms to grab stuff in the open and obvious environment of the house serves no purpose, and this part of the game could have just as easily been replaced by a menu where you just check boxes for what you want, because there's no challenge in grabbing it.  Sadly, this chapter of the game, which I thought had kind of appealing graphics, represented the gameplay, and is the best area for them to expand upon ends after only a minute, leading to the next, even more poorly executed chapter.

After grabbing supplies, the gamplay completely changes one you get in your shelter... no more 3D world to interact with anymore, just a static image of your characters sitting around a table in a boring room, with nothing for you to interact with.  The only movement on screen is a very annoying fly, which kept tricking me into thinking there was a fly on my monitor, which I didn't appreciate, although in the game's defense, I guess that means at least something was done well!  So anyways, this boring, static image is the last thing you'll see in this game, because it's the entireity of the gameplay from here on out.  Your characters' show signs of sickness and health, otherwise, not much changes.

You start each day with the monotonous, boring task of assigning who in the party gets food, water, or medicine that day.  You do this by clicking the only clickable thing, your survival log
date:
which is annoyingly in the bottom right corner of the screen.  It pops up, and gives you a report on the day's events, and your character's health, so you don't even need the graphical representation at all.  The authors of the journal content think they're a lot more funny than they are... Talking about dancing cockroaches in a nuclear war OVER AND OVER AND OVER again was never entertaining, and popped up almost every one of the 40ish days I survived my first time playing.  After reading the poorly-written (it's seriously high-school level content... not the grammar or spelling, just the low quality) story about the day and assigning resources to characters, the next page allows you to choose to send an explorer topside to try to scavenge things (presuming at least one is in good enough health to do so), or not, and a subsequent page lets you give them items to take with them (gas mask, axe, etc).  Once those few, grindy, obvious, monotonous tasks are done, you click finish... and that's literally the entire game.  That journal cycle repeats, with some random events destroying or giving you resources, and minor decisions needing to be made every day, until either you survive until a random day that the military rescues you, or your party dies.

The entire game could have been text based, and programmed on a TI-82 calculator by a novice programmer in just a day or two, tops... very sophomoric, and very disappointing.

The developers need to fix their 3D engine issues, make that part of the game play smooth, as well as expand it to be 99% of the gameplay... why the heck are we clicking characters to send them scavenging for supplies on their own, while the player is stuck in the boring bunker?  We should be playing as those players, scavenging, fighting, avoiding danger, and bartering with NPCs, not having it done off screen!

In short, this game has a lot of major problems with it, but hope isn't lost, they have the development room to save the title and make it fun to play, but in all honesty, the concept and playstyle has already been done much better by This War of Mine, and it'd take a lot of ingenuity to differentiate 60 Seconds! from it, and stand on its own merits.

reviewText:
To sum up my review: Too little control.
There is little if any control you have over the outcome of the events that happen in this game.
Mostly it involves who you feed and who you decide to send to the surface.

Sometimes events pop up and you have to make a yes or no decision, but it doesnt really matter, because either yes or no could be wrong. So once again, no real control.

Events also appear which require you to have certain items. The items you need and the order in which you need them is also random.
And of course you dont have enough time in 60 seconds to pick all the items up.

So once again, too little control.

A very interesting concept though.

Honestly if you want to see what its about, I recommed getting it in a sale, because it will not entertain you more than an hour.

I could feel the beating of my heart right when i was running out of time and i still needed to pickup more water or find out where was my fat daughter or my mad wife. After that
recommended: the game should be called "60 hours" because that's the amount of time you want to play it without a single break.\n\nMy thoughts about this game:Some reviews are all about being funny and others are not even close. hoursPlayed: the "man of the house" whose wife Dolores will left him at the first sign of problems. You have a lovely daughter called Mary Jane who is hungry all the time and Timmy: the typical kid who is a "good boy". reviewText:
Hello, today i will be reviewing 60 soups.

60 soups is a dark comedy soup adventure of scavenge and soup. You have to collect soup and maybe rescue your wife but not your children before the bomb hits, you will make easy choices, such as letting your child eat soup, or not eat soup and die. You can also eat the soup.

Heat the soup.
Sleep in soup
Talk to the soup.
Be friends with the soup.
Get in a long term relation ship with the soup.
Hunt soup.
Let your children die for soup.
SOUP.

Now about the gameplay, there are 2 parts. The scavenging one (grab soup, your family is useless) in which you have 60 seconds to grab all the soup you can.

It has teached me life lessons such as:

2 soup cans are more important than your:

Wife

Daughter

Son

Living is all about tomato soup.

Its really tasty

Soup is love, soup is life.

Now the second part of the game is the survival part. Its all about soup.

10/10 Would eat soup again.  You know soup loses its meaning when you say it too many times. Maybe after all its SOAP.....

reviewText:
Fun, yet challenging, take on the dark post-apocalyptic theme. A simple concept executed with a brilliant balance of complexity and addictabillity.

Easy, mediumm, or hard, you only get 60 seconds - hence the name of the game - to collect supplies (including your loved ones) from your house, before a mad dash to take cover in your underground bomb-shelter as your neighbourhood is being nuked above.

You can perfect your gathering skills in Scavenger mode, hone your stamina skills in survival mode, or play out a complete scenario in Apocalypse mode - in which you first scavenge your supplies and family, and then see how long you can hold out in your shelter with just the supplies you've brought with you.

Quite soon you will find it necessary to go out into the radiated wasteland of suburbia for more supplies. Well, not always you ... often it's your children. You will encounter various events and make life or death decisions along the way. Things can get quite brutal.

Light humour and cartoon style makes this a great game the whole family can enjoy. Highly recommended.

Congrats to the development team on a very clever release. +5 Soup for you! ;-)

A really creative idea of a survival game that lets you gather supplies and family members from your house during a period of 60 seconds, the house is also randomly generated (aswell as the supplies spread out) so forget about learning where everything is. (That's the shelter), from here on its luck that will keep you alive (and to some degree the items you brought with you)

I also learned from this game that you would not have been able to survive in a shelter alone with just a checkers board

Because naturally the first time the only thing i brought with me was a checkers board so that i could turn my shelter into a future fallout gambling den.

reviewText:
I find 60 Seconds! quite interesting and omnious since it's allmost like a fallout shelter simulator. But then the omnious elements of the game comes to life  when you're frantically rushing through your house trying to grab everything essential for your survival whilst listening to panic inducing music, after that when you enter the shelter you get to see characters health and apperance decompose after being exposed to different hazardous materials or not getting sufficient healthcare and food.

I would have not recommed this game since i got into a slighty sad mood after i felt such a pity for the poor characters who tried to survive in the claustrophobic bunker. But since that is just a personal feeling which deteriorates my game expirience i thought it would be unfair to not recommend this well made game.

Exclude my personal feelings and it would be a fairly priced game with quite much replayability and humor.

I give 60 Seconds! a 7/10

reviewText:
While I wouldn't say this is a game you could spend countless hours on every day, it's a fantastic game to own if you're looking for something that will take you ~30-40 minutes
Very fun prepping mini-game, but that's only part of it. The rest of the game is a sort of choose your own adventure style game, where you must manage your food and water with whatever family you brought with you. While I do find myself encountering the same events quite frequently, whether or not I have the item the event needs to fulfil properly, and even just RNG, makes it so every game has never played out the exact same way.

In Summary: Nothing you'd spend tons of hours on, but perfect for a quick game or two sometimes

reviewText: 60 Seconds, is a very fun strategy based, post-apocalyptic game. There may not be much gameplay, but the little gameplay that there is, can turn the tables on if you get rescued or not. The strategy part of this game is amazing, it produces many different scenarios each game you play, while also making very tough decisions to make, such as which sick/injured person should get the ONLY MEDKIT! Which makes the game take a turn. You may get rescued out of chance, or if you're really good at the game. reviewText:
Positives:
-Art style is fantastic
-Log book & animations are quite humourous
-The smash & grab in the house is quite fun (when I can ACTUALLY grab)
-Different endings every play through
-Easy enough controls (my 7 year old played it with ease)

Negatives:

-I feel as if there is NO way to win on Apocalypse mode

reviewText:
Beat the game on normal difficulty. Is definitely fun, although there's not much variety in events. All of the makes of a great game are here, and it's definitely very difficult to keep yourself from losing people.

The basics of the game go like this:
1) Start in a house filled with stuff, you have 60 seconds to obtain all of the materials you have and literally throw them down a hatch (including your family lol).
2) Make it down the hatch before the 60 seconds are up, if you don't you're down 1 man from the get go.
3) Survive until you start getting military radio broadcasts telling you some task the military wants you to complete.
4) Complete said tasks.
5) After completing some amount of tasks actually open the door to let the military rescue you (this is actually a scary choice to make since they could potentially be raiders).

All in all it's a fun game, but like I said at the beginning there's not a ton of variety in the random events, there's a pool of maybe 30 events it feels like. Also the military events that occur require you to have a random item to complete them, and since you get most of your stuff at the beginning and then just sporadically and uncommonly find them from then on it can feel like the actual win condition" of the game is way more luck based than skill based. This isn't to say survival is easy though. It just feels like survival is more a roll of the dice than anything you choose to do or not to do.

Overall I'd say it's a very good game
date: has an amazing thematic and art style it sticks to very well
recommended: and can be a little humorous at times. It just doesn't have quite enough content for me to say it's one of the best indies released recently.\n\nI'll give it a 7/10 for those of you who are too lazy and don't want to bother reading pros and cons and decide how good it is for yourself."

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S3PDVlXgC8E

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch if you are looking for a more in-depth review

60 seconds is a post-apocalyptic survival, turn based choose your own adventure style game. The graphics of the game are simple, in a 2d style. The music is decent, and does a good job of setting the tone throughout the game. The game also offers numerous steam achievements, which is appreciated.

The premise of the game is that there is a global disaster (nuclear) and you are given 60 seconds at the beginning of the game to grab up whatever supplies you can for your basement disaster shelter. This includes food, weapons, first aid, and family members. The decisions on what you bring with you into the game drastically affect how the rest of the game plays out.  The rest of the game is more choose your own adventure, where you choose whether or not to venture outside for further supplies, how much or little food you can ration to family members and when.

As time progresses, you become attached and invested in the family's survival. Losing family members due to starvation or illness adds weight to the survivors atmosphere. You may be more willing to make more risky choices such as stealing from other survivors. Just because you are in a shelter does not necessarily mean that you will survive.

The goal of the game is to survive until the army comes to save you, but you don't know when, or if, that will happen. The game hits on the nature of humanity well, and forces you to make decisions that you wouldn't normally make, such as whether or not to put your life at risk to help others, or just try to survive on your own. It's a classic example of a game that's easy to play, but hard to master. The game never disrespects you, or make your time feels wasted. This is an easy recommend.

Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here.
http://www.youtube.com/c/SocioPsycho

reviewText:
This game is all about the luck of the draw. If you're in to random chance, this game is for you. There's very little strategy involved, if really any at all. The game can decide to be nice to you, which is incredibly rare, but more often than not it just never gives you what you need when you desperately need it. It's humorous, but that wears off quickly when you have lost 49 out of your 50 games. Not to mention the controls for the very, VERY limited portion of the game of it's namesake where you have a minute to grab whatever you feel is essential to survive in your bomb shelter, are incredibly stiff and awkward, with items sandwiched next to each other, each item having different carrying capacity requirements that when combined end up making you grabbing things you didn't intend to get.

However the difficulty of trying to actually survive in your nuclear fallout shelter is what really kills it for me.  With how precious certain items are, (I.E. the Radio, Scout Handbook, Medkit) there are too many events that occur that will destroy such invaluable items in one go and your only option is to save one of them if you actually have said items. Considering the only real way to replenish any lost items is to trek and scavenge the surface (of which you have absolutely no control over the fate of whoever gets sent), there's absolutely no guaruntee you'll ever get what you actually need. If the events don't destroy your items, there are other events at complete random with no warning, where you will face some bizarre scenario in which the only way to prevent your family from getting hurt, sick, going insane, is to have a very specific item(s), but a lot of times you won't actually have them because you either didn't bring with you intially to the shelter, got it destroyed in an event, used it already, or sent it out with a family member when they went scavenging to up your miniscule chance of getting ANOTHER specific item you desperately need (and will probably not get and end up losing that item you sent out with your family member, because that's a possibility too).

To add insult to injury on those compounded problems that are steadily mounting over your family, the scavenging portion is just as unforgiving and aggravating, which is literally, your only real lifeline to survivng. If you never scavenge, you will assuredly lose the game. Again, it's pure luck of the draw, even if you have a required item to help your family out scavenging, you still stand a pretty decent chance to have them come back hurt, sick, or just never come back (I.E. In the early portion of the game when radioactive fallout is a threat and you have a gas mask that's supposed to lessen your chances of your family getting sick, it's too common an occurance that they still get sick anyway, with that item being broken in the process somehow). Keep in mind, at this part of the game (which sadly consists of the majority of the time you will spend playing) besides making basic decisions such as nourishing your family with food+water, dealing with random RNG scenarios, and deciding when you send out someone on a scav run, EVERY SINGLE BIT OF IT, is completely up to random chance. ALL OF IT. So it's literally just pure luck whether or not your situation ever improves or deteriorates (the latter being frustratingly too common, even on normal difficulty). They should have named this game: Gambling your life: Post-apocalyptic edition".

So unless that's really your thing
date: I absolutely do NOT recommend this game. 2 out of 10."

reviewText:
I bought this game as part of the Steam 2015 Summer Sale.. it looked a lot of fun and like it might help tide me over until November 10 which as post apocalyptic gaming fans know is the release for the new Fallout game.

The game is quirky and fun. You play a suburban dad during a nuclear apocalypse trying to survive with his family.. problem is you only have 1 minute to grab everything you need to survive for 20 days when the military will come and get you.

Controls are easy to learn and the game is a relatively simple point and click control system. There are several modes including apocalypse and scavenging each of which has different goals.

My only problem with this game is that the movement is somewhat glitched- even pressing space to make Ted move faster is not very effective. This is a problem when gathering supplies and family members. It is not a long game by a long shot but it is fun.. a lot of fun. I would recommend this for anyone who likes post apocalyptic survival games.

reviewText:
This game is mostly a text adventure survival resource manager where you play as the father of a family of four living in a fallout shelter after the USA has been nuked super hard. Besides the choose-your-own-adventure style of story and the random encounters here and there, there are also a handful of things that make this game unique compared to other survival resource managers.

For starters, the biggest unique aspect of this game (maybe other games have something similar I don't know) is the game's namesake. At the start of each instance of this game you have 60 seconds to run around your house, which is a full (but not exactly award-winning) 3D environment where you have to gather supplies and family members. At all times you only have four inventories slots and certain items/all family members take up more than one slot, so you constantly have to pick up what you can, drop them all in the shelter, and repeat until the 60 seconds are up and you dive into the shelter yourself, leaving behind any goods and family members you didn't pick up. That's when the meat of the game comes out.

The bulk of the game after the mad dash to grab resources, the game becomes your standard resource manager text adventure when you have to work with the items and supplies that you gathered and ration the food and water you have between yourself and your family (if you brought any of them with you). The events are varied and interesting, and a lot of events reward you or punish you for grabbing or forgetting certain items during the 60 seconds. Somebody's trying to break into the shelter? Too bad you forgot to grab a weapon. You're out of medicine, but you can totally turn that bug spray into medicine without any side effects, right? Etc, Etc. There's also a reference to other games and such here and there, such as a man in blue asking you for a water chip, but I'm not certain of the variety of them all.

In terms of fine detail, one thing that really stands out to me about this game is your location constantly changes depending on the resources you have and the status of your family. Family members will be visibly sick and tired depending on the circumstances, while the resources you have will be shown sitting around the shelter as time goes on. These all change constantly, such as a flashlight breaking being shown as the flashlight sitting on it's usual space on the shelf but now broken or your son from being perfectly fine to having an empty soup can on his head because he went nuts.

As far as quality goes, this game is pretty good looking. The sprites and art all look stellar, however the 3D area of the 60 seconds section is not exactly amazing. Also, computers that are not exactly made for gaming may have a hard time running the 3D section of the game and the best way to avoid that for me at least is to lower the quality and resolution (by a lot), exit to the menu, then set everything back to the highest quality for the text adventure portion. There's also options where you can play just the text adventure portion and start out with randomized supplies/survivors, or play just the 60 second mad grab for supplies. Of course there's a tutorial as well so you can learn the basics but yeah.

Overall, this is a pretty good game if you're into text adventures, resource managers, and games like that. Beware if your computer is not a gaming computer (a non-Alienware laptop or something kind of old) because you might have trouble with the framerate on the 60 seconds section of the game, but the rest of the game runs fine otherwise. If you have the money for it, I suggest you buy it.

reviewText:
I don't recommend this as full price. Theres a lot of good to this game, but when you get the same daily scenario three or four days in a row and certain mechanics that don't make sense it just bugs me. What's worse this is mainly a text based game, so when you get that you either put a lot of effort into the words or a lot of effort into gameplay and choices. It has some good writing but not enough to make sense. Some of the options for your scenarios don't make sense and the next day aren't explained what happened so I'm just like.. alright.

Your people are then gone for 3 -5 days straight while looting. okay cool I like a challenge but the scenarios then don't match up saying this person just went to a neighbors house? Like that doesn't take a week to do.. And when you perish I don't quite get how that concept works when I still have characters alive and left..

It's just silly and not worth full price. Was fun for 5 min or so and I'll play again eventually. Just could do with a lot of work and it'd be an amazing game. I love the 60 second idea. Until then I don't really recommend.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ng7bJ04qxyo

A nice little indie title that combines simple, reflex based arcade game with This War of Mine survival mechanics and some gruesome humor. You start the game in a procedurally generated house and you have only 60 seconds to bring family members, food, water and every potentially useful tool you can to your shelter. Of course you have limited equipment slots, so you have to run there and back again like crazy and decide what is more important - your son, or perhaps a radio that will allow you to listen to army broadcasts and be able to prepare for what is coming.

After the time is up, a nuclear bomb explodes and you begin the second, more important, longer part of the game. You have to survive several weeks in your shelter, using what you were able to collect. Every day you have to make difficult choices, like who are you going to feed with your limited resources, who is going to risk exploring the nuclear wasteland in order to find more useful stuff, what piece of equipment to save during an earthquake and so on. Almost everything is randomized, so no two campaigns are the same. It's not as complex, nor engaging as This War of Mine, but the variety of events is large enough to keep you going for several hours. I also like the art style of the game - it's very simplistic, yet fun. Be aware that there is quite a lot of text to read in the second part of the game and that you are going to fail time and again, as the random events can really make a mess of your shelter!
