reviewText:
Gone in 60 Seconds

There’s not a lot you can do in 60 seconds.
Boil a kettle, nuke something in the microwave, maybe have a wee, of course if you’re Nicolas Cage then could hot wire a car, but that’s Hollywood for you.
But what if your future and that of your family depended on the decisions you made over one short pressure filled minute?


Busy Doing Nothing

Imagine a situation where you’re sitting at home.
Glancing around you can see all sorts of junk begging to be tidied away; maybe if you leave it long enough your wife and kids (who are around the house somewhere) might get around to doing it.
As you idly wonder who left a crate of bottled water in the corner of the living room a screeching noise shatters the silence.

You’re filled with dread as you realise that it’s the sound of the early warning system wailing outside.
We knew politicians would be the death of us and it seems that day has finally come.
The bombers must already be on their way, carrying their payloads of nuclear Armageddon,
The world is about to end...


Don’t Worry, Be Happy

... But don’t worry, you’ve prepared, unlike most of the other saps who are about to take a crash course in nuclear fission you had the foresight to install a nuclear bunker under your house!
You smile smugly to yourself, all that time playing fallout was well spent after all and in a few seconds you’ll be sitting safely in your cosy vault as the world above you turns into a radioactive wasteland.


Tick Tock

Moving for the shelter your eyes again drift to the crate of bottled water and an awful realisation washes all traces of smugness away.
You might have had the foresight to build a fallout shelter, but you never did get around to filling it with supplies did you?
Cursing your laziness you look desperately around the room, what items are you going to need in your shelter?
Food, Water, maybe the wife and kids to keep you company?
The alarms are still wailing outside, how much warning do they give you?
60 seconds?
Dashing towards the bottled water you trip over a can of soup, stumble and crash into a chair, if only your house wasn’t in such a mess!
Which room are the kids in anyway?
... tick... tock...


Pre-Apocalypse

This is the premise behind the first part “60 Seconds” a unique little survival title developed by Robot Gentleman Studios.
I say the first part, because “60 Seconds” is split into two very distinct yet connected games.
The first part of the game is a quick and frantic “treasure hunt” around your house.
You’ll control your character as he runs and stumbles through the various rooms searching for supplies to take down into the bunker.
You’re given a few short seconds to explore your surroundings before the sirens blare and the countdown begins, this time is vital to quickly scan around the layout of your house and look for the locations of useful items. (This changes every time you play!)


Supermarket Sweep

Before you’ve had chance to complete your stock take the countdown will begin, it’s time to start grabbing those supplies and dropping them down the hatch into your vault.
It’s not as simple as grabbing everything in one go either, you can only carry so much at a time, this leads to a frantic dash through the various rooms with armfuls of tinned food or bottled water.
This is 60 seconds of sandbox physics mayhem.

Furniture will go flying, objects will get in your way and you’ll be looking for one thing and get distracted by something else.
A radio might be useful to keep in touch with the outside world, maybe a good book would help stave off the boredom, there must be a first aid kit somewhere, etc.
These are the thoughts that will go through your head as you crash passed tables and fall over chairs in the rush.
It’s an ultra intense supermarket sweep and it’s as fun as it is frustrating!


Take Shelter

This is just the beginning, after diving into the bunker yourself, you’ll get to experience vault life and ration out those precious supplies to prolong your existence (and that of your family if you got around to saving them) for as long as possible.

Of course, if you got distracted by something shiny and didn’t make it into the shelter in time then you’ll be dead and need to start a new game, so let’s assume you did make it, because it’s in the shelter that the real fun starts.


Post-Apocalypse

The game changes pace in the shelter and becomes a short tongue in cheek survival adventure.
You’ll spend the remainder of the game looking at a static screen of yourself and any rescued family members sitting in the vault along with whatever supplies you managed to scavenge.

Each day this screen will be updated to reflect any changes in your little vault, including the ever dwindling supplies sitting on the shelf behind you.
Your food and water will almost certainly require rationing if you’re to last until help arrives, keep someone hungry or thirsty for too long though and they’ll get sick and die.

Other items you threw into the shelter could well prove useful too, you see, strange things happen when you’re cooped up in a vault.
A board game might be enough to stave off madness and a can of bug spray might be handy if you don’t want to share your bunker with some new scuttling friends.


Dear Diary

Like a post apocalyptic Adrian Mole, you keep a diary in the vault, but there’s more to write about than the dwindling water supplies.
Vault life is more eventful than you might think, random events happen every day and it’s these events that drive the narrative forward.
Each day you will go through food and water rationing, deciding who (if anyone) gets something to eat or drink that day.You’ll then read through the vault diary,
it’ll cover the health and moods of your surviving family members and report on any interesting events that occurred that day.


Kevin Costner or Mad Max?

Mutants, bandits, a nice game of scrabble, anything could happen as you wait out the apocalypse and most of these events will require you to make a decision which will impact the narrative as the days progress.

There’s a banging on the vault door, It could be a post apocalyptic mailman delivering some goodies, or it could just as likely be a gang of bandits fresh from the set of Mad Max, do you answer it? Well that’s up to you.


Valued in the Vault

The outcome of many of these events will depend on the salvaged items from the first part of the game.
If a radioactive bug bites a family member, you’d better hope you bought a first aid kit with you or the consequences might prove surprising.

Your first play through will give you an idea of the importance of the various items you ignored whilst foraging for cans of soup to bring down into the vault.
This game will quickly teach you that no matter how innocuous an item seems, it could well prove useful in the vault.


Keep Taking the Tablets

60 Seconds is a refreshing and quirky little game but It definitely feels like a tablet conversion.
It’s quick to play and immediately addictive which is great, unfortunately, like most mobile gaming ports, it can feel a little shallow and become repetitive pretty quickly.
Having said that, it’s priced to reflect this short term appeal and there is no denying the hours of entertainment you’ll get out of playing it.

60 seconds isn’t looking for a relationship, it’s looking for a fling.
Its fun whilst it lasts, you’re going to enjoy it but you probably won’t remember it in the morning.
It’s the one night stand of post apocalyptic gaming!

reviewText: There's little to no skill involved. You dash around a house that you're unfamiliar with while the camera isn't fixed over your character. It sways and swerves, and there's an odd little delay everytime you pick an item up that slows you down a lot. Your family doesn't have the mindfulness to run into the bunker itself, and the bunker has very little stored in it. Most of what you hide with comes from the 60 seconds you're running around to grab stuff. You can't tell your family to grab things either like how in real life, families have emergency plans of what to grab, where to go, who to call, and what to do.\n\nThe game doesn't progress either. Everytime you play is the same as the last, so you can't bank up" items from previous run throughs as a reward for getting so and so far. This is especially annoying with the random events that can destroy your items. There's no way to flood-proof your bunker

reviewText:
Unbeatable game, even on EASY difficulty...

I can not express how disappointed I am, especially becasue I was really excited about this game from the moment I saw the trailer, it really dragged me into buying it.

I've spent 4 hours playing the game and went through numerous game runs. Most I made it was over 60 days. The worst part about this game is the BANDITS. I had a gun, a padlock and an axe and they came every second day(wtf?!) until I used up all three of my items and couldn't defend myself anymore. The fourth time they came it was an instant game over because they took over my shelter.

When I tried to get rescued by the army or other survivors they always wanted me to do something with an item I didn't have and it kept repeating itself over and over again. Food and water were NEVER a problem. What bothered me the most was that the expeditions I sent out always came back without any useful items, especially the ones I needed to get rescued.

I rage quit after I realised I spent all of those hours ingame without getting any satisfaction at all...

reviewText:
A playful jab at Cold War Americana, a choose your own adventure serial that could use more effort overall, and a game, in that order.

The art style effectively parodies the Reagan era suburban family.  Most of the graphics are two dimentional sketches in which beauty will be in the eye of the beholder, but I largely found unimpressive and lacking in variety.  The three dimentional gameplay segment is function, but equally forgettable art wise.  Music also fails to linger after the game is switched off.

The game is effectively two games in one.  The first being a time management puzzle evocative of the game's title.  The second being a decision driven visual novel.  The two elements don't inherently feel connected, save that your performance in the former slightly enhances your experience of the latter.  The game itself seems to realize this as either segment can be played independent of the other through some of the default options.  For two games, two reviews are in order.

The time management puzzle is a glorified random number generator.  Tasked with procuring the best and most necessary supplies for your fallout shelter in 60 seconds, the fact that all supplies are randomly scattered throughout the house on each playthrough, while the house's layout is fixed, means that you'll naturally develop an optimal path for maximum stuff accumulation, hoping that the correct stuff is in the correct place.  In short, the segment plays itself for the most part, aside from the infusion of varience in the form of player mistakes.  Controls are slippery and require spamming clicks to force the avatar to execute the desired action, no doubt to raise tension but frustrating nevertheless.

The visual novel is full of delightful anachronisms that may induce a hee hawing from time to time, but they do repeat themselves frequently.  You'll soon find yourself skipping through the family status updates and consequences of previous decisions to get to the meat and potatoes of your upcoming encounter.  Most of the decisions in the game are focused on rewarding you for having the correct tool when prompted (or inversely punishing you for not having or using said tool).  Some choices rely on your memory of previous encounters or informtion, which deliver a more satisfying sense of accomplishment when overcome and a sense of fair play on the game's part when you fall prey to them.  For the most part though, luck is a large factor, making the exercise less about achieving victory and more about enjoying the story of your family victimized by the ravages of a pulp fiction nuclear holocaust.

Your $10.00s will buy you a few hours of entertainment from this title before it starts collecting virtual dust on your virtual shelf, awaiting the next major content update that may never come.  You can do worse for the money, but you also could do better, and with the release of games like Stardew Valley, I find myself expecting more from my indie titles nowadays.  If the idea of a pulpy, witty game about nuclear war and American values interests you, the Fallout series has been scratching that itch since the 1990s (Those games from the 1990s are likely obtainable at a comparable price tag to this title and absolutely dominate in comparison regarding content).  Consequence driven visual novel lovers can get a more rewarding experience from the Telltale games or a dedicated visual novel game.

reviewText:
I've played 60 seconds for about 60 minutes so far and am liking it. No tutorial needed, very easy to pick up and start playing. It takes some elements from This war of mine, for example being forced to make choices for your survival or helping others who might help you later. It also has a similar depressing atmosphere, although the devs have added a good dose of humor into the mix.

You start out in your house with the alarms going off warning about an incoming nuclear attack. You have 60 seconds to run around, pick up some resources (including famil y members) and dump them into the shelter. You then hop into the shelter yourself and the real game starts. Every 'round' you have to make decisions on how to ration food and other supplies, send people out for a scavenging hunt, etc. you will be faced with a lot of obstacles and things will generally not go very well. At least they did not go well for me :)

pros : easy to pick up, humor
cons : the initial stage of collecting resources is not very easy to control (a little messy)

reviewText:
It's like those age old decision making text games, where you sweat on what the next page will be.

It was very fun to play it making different decisions each time. After a few plays (3 hours), failing a lot and surviving a long time once and being rescued once, I don't find myself wanting to replay. This content limitation was my only problem but you can only expect so much for the price paid.

An interesting concept, easy to pick up, no controls to learn, that will serve you a weekend of fun.
Buy when on sale: It's not worth the full price tag.

reviewText:
tldr: The game gets incredibly boring and I explain why. Maybe DLC can fix that, I will not come back for this though.

Day 1
the alarm goes off and I have 60 seconds to frantically grab everything I can think of and throw it down into the bunker. Sadly, I forgot to think of my son.

Day 5
We are all good, there's enough food and water and I'm looking forward to see how far our supplies can take us. Nobody seems to care that we left little Timmy to die in a nuclear strike.

Day 9
We are holding up. We eat mushrooms that grow on the shelterwalls, kill giant mutated rats and spiders with our trusty axe and break our radio. Struggles, challenges, curiosity for what will hit us next, nice game so far!

Day 15
All we can think about is that broken radio that we could have used every single day otherwise. My daughter turns into a mutant, becomes resistent to radiation and doesn't require anything to drink anymore. Nobody notices.

Day 25
We managed to find another radio. Finally we can hear the military instruct citizens to leave playing cards by the bus stop to signal they are around. Sadly we don't have any.  My daughter goes for expeditions as often as possible while I repel frequent bandit attacks with our rifle. My wife went crazy somewhere along the way and left us.


Day 40
The military regularly instructs citizens to leave playing cards near the bus stop. We ignore the order everytime because we can't find any stupid cards. Food and water is still no problem, we are even stockpiling, but that could have to do with the fact that we are only 2 people and only I myself need to drink at all. Also it was the easy difficulty.

Day 69
Still no ♥♥♥♥ing cards, still regular bandit attacks that can be defended simply by clicking the rifle and the next button".

Day 91
Can't find playing cards. Same ♥♥♥♥ everyday. There are some new things like a dog that showed up a week ago or so and once the vent system broke and had to be fixed
date: the game isn't COMPLETELY barren of new content but I am bored as ♥♥♥♥ and I decide not to play the game on a harder difficulty again
recommended:
despite the replayability with different start equipment.

Day 111
I get an achievement for making it this far. Still no cards and next to no interesting stuff happening. I stop playing.

The game tries and it's alright-ish
voteText: but it's not enough. If you like the concept
helpfulPercent: try This War of Mine instead.\n"

reviewText: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. I gave you guys a fair warning. I have a Macbook Pro running OS Yosemite and this game constantly crashes. More than 80% of the time I can't even load the game without it crashing and having to hard-reset the computer to access the desktop, and even when it does load I cannot play any other gameplay modes except the survival mode. If I chose any other game-mode it will most certainly crash. No it is not a problem with my computer as it is fine loading any other game, including ones that are much more resource hungry than this game. I honestly regret buying this game and I want a refund. Due to my very low income, I don't spend any money on luxuries in my life except games on steam, and even then I only try to purchase games that are independent based and try to support the underdog developers and I don't expect the sun and the moon for the money that I spent on the game, but at least I expect to be able to run it. I will not be purchasing any other games from this developer and I highly recommend that no one else does either.

reviewText:
***Possible spoilers***

Get prepared for some painful times as this game is totally unfair. One game you might get heaps of food but no water, the next vice versa. It's just a little too random and at times it even appears to strategically screw you over as hard as possible.

Apparently clicking on things in the bunker does something!?. I was hoping that when one of my people got injured clicking on flies may help them heal instead of it progressing to sickness but that did not work. I may have been able to trigger the bug spray to medikit event by clicking on one of them but it would take more playthroughs than I am willing to do to confirm.

You need to get rescued sucessfully in all modes and on all difficulty levels to get all of the achievments. Of over 60 play throughs I was able to get rescued twice on easy.
Every playthrough is pretty much the same there are just not enough different events. I hope the free DLC will fix these issues until then this game will sit dormant in my inventory.

All in all fun for a few hours then frustrating. 2/5 will play again when the dlc comes out.

Tips. Press strafe and forward to accelertate Ted quicker through the house. Just spam pickup button when trying to get items it's horribly unresponsive. I would suggest to not take all family members as your supplies will get used up quicker.

reviewText:
Even at the price of ten bucks, it's not sufficient value for the money. The scavenging feature is innovative and fun, but the bulk of the game is frustrating from a UI perspective due to poor presentation of necessary information in relation to the controls you use to make decisions based off of that information.

Also, the survival part in the bunkers is only superficially explained by the tutorial. Hunger and thirst are sufficiently explained, but tiredness and insanity are left to the player to figure out. You might think that's because it's left as an excercise for the player to figure out, but it's really a case of Guide Dang It because there's little to no feedback tying your actions to results (e.g. Timmy is no longer sick because you did x.)

I gave it 103 minutes. Only 20 of that was fun gameplay past the tutorial. Requested a refund before I was stuck with it. The potential to improve the game is there, but the following need to happen:
The page where you decide to ration needs to display the family status right there on the page where you make the decisions. Having to move the journal out of the way to check each family member (or paging back and forth) is just bad UI design.
Even if you leave it for the player to figure out cause and effect, once the player has figured it out, the game needs to tie cause and effect together. It's too hard to figure out if Timmy is no longer sick/insane because I kept giving him food and water, because of a random event, or just pure RNG.
I would suggest that the debuffs on family members be given a duration. That would inherently add a layer of strategy to the game. I.e. Timmy will snap out of it in about x days. Maybe finding him a new card game would help him come around sooner?" If it pleases you
date: maybe tie getting this information to having certain items in your possession.\nThe game as it stands is only worth about $0.99. At 20 minutes of fun for $10
hoursPlayed: Fallout 4 + season pass cost me $100 for 126.5 hours of fun so far. Unless my math is failing me (and that wouldn't be the first time) that's just shy of $0.02/minute. It's not about indie vs. AAA
voteText: or the price of the game
helpfulPercent: it's the value. Also
votesHelpful: it's not about graphics. I still play Dwarf Fortress
votesFunny: although free
commentsCount: is a bunch of ASCII characters on the screen. I've probably sunk about 300 hours into that game.\n\nYou know
column16: I need to write Tarn Adams and donate - I just realized that even if I donated $100
column17: DF has still provided me superior value to even Fallout 4."

reviewText:
well yeah ummm
Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText:
60 Seconds is not a bad game by any means.  The first part of the game, collecting items and rushing to the shelter in 60 seconds is actually quite compelling.  But after you are in the shelter, things become dull pretty quickly.  The game has very few visualizations and there isn't much to do with your characters other than feed and water them from day to day between missions until your supplies run out or you die from something situationally.

This formula might work on a mobile game that cost a few dollars, but for almost $10 as of the writing of this review, the price is quite steep.  You can spend that $10 on two or three older AAA titles and squeeze hundreds of hours out of them for the price of one or two hours of entertainment in this game.

So, in summary, the game is well done for what it is, but given the price and the medium it is little fun for a lot of money.

reviewText:
At first look this game seemed to be worth the money. The key word here is at first look. The fun part is running around gathering things before the nuclear apocalypse strikes, however, that's where the fun pretty much ends.

Check out my Let's Play here: https://www.youtube.com/analytics?o=U#dt=nt,fe=16580,fr=lw-001,fs=16553;fc=1,fcr=0,fi=v-u9F1CbVSGOo,r=realtime


I can't help but feel that this game could have been so much more, may be it will still be one day.

The running around collecting things is a bit clunky at best, not to mention that 60 seconds is not enough time at all and you will be force to forgo a loved one or some other essential items.

After the 60 seconds is over the game becomes pretty much text base. It wouldn't be all that bad if the dialog always made sense, but in my case where all of my family members died and only the father survived the dialog keep saying 'we' as if the other member of the family was still alive.

It's not horrible for 8 bucks, but don't expect at of lot of replay value here.

My biggest complaint is the gameplay, I would have loved to see more of the 60 seconds game play instead of the bunkers as things got mostly boring for me.

Also the other game play modes are nothing but a gimmick.

I am really saddened by this game. I could have have been great and innovative, but it was a lackluster after the 60 seconds.

Great concept, but poorly executed.

reviewText:
tl;dr: It's definitely cute/funny and has good writing. But that's something that adds to a game. This has hope, but the devs need to fix it up a bit more. 6/10. Saw what was going on, and even though it's a bit mediocre, it still succeeds in achieving it. But just barely.

In depth:

There are two main selling points to this game. Both of which the devs are kinda messing up atm... These are:
1. The scavenge aspect
and
2. The survival aspect
Where many games only have one of these, this game is unique in that it has you find your own resources in a time limit and then survive off what you grabbed for however long you can/rescue takes. Pretty neat concept, and the humor also adds to it. Would be an appropriately priced game if...

1. The scavenge aspect wasn't so clunky. It is impossible to use arrow key controls, you have to go middle-school Runescape style with the mouse (point and click). Combined that with other slow gameplay such as it taking multiple clicks to pick an item up and really bad camera angles with no way to change them besides moving and hoping it gets less awkward. This is exacerbated by the 60 second timer, since you're trying to rush as quickly as possible. So I just skip this section, it's too clunky right now to be fun.
2. The more thoughtful side (survival)....was more thoughtful. On the plus side, there's some great work being done by the devs on what makes/breaks events, what is good and bad, how interacting with items helps you. On the negative side, they refuse to say what that is. Apparently clicking the map helps/hurts. They won't say how. Having certain events helps/hurts. They won't say how. You're basically stuck playing chess knowing only how to move the pawns, and anytime you try moving a different piece you get yelled at by the other player. You also don't know if the piece actually moved or not. Have fun :P
The second issue with the survival side is you don't really make choices so much as you cross your fingers and hope for the best.  If the military tells you to ditch your gun, you ditch your gun. If they tell you to cut down trees, you cut down trees. You don;t have an axe? Too bad, you will never get past that prompt until you find leprechaun gold on a scavenger trip. There's no knowable" way to tell your scavenger to look for something specific. There may be a way (like clicking on the map
date: or where the item is supposed to be) but if there is the devs aren't sharing (aka see issue 1
recommended: you have no idea wtf you're doing).  This is also the same for other prompts. For example a gambler comes and wagers two water on a game of cards. You could win and get 2 water
voteText: or just refuse and not win/lose anything. But you can't actively try to increase your water supply
helpfulPercent: food supply
votesFunny: issue 1- the devs aren't sharing. Followed by the fact that your choices can go either way (I've planted a radiation plant that has resulted in both eating 2 cans of food and giving me 4 cans of food with no obvious indicators of how I influenced its growth) it's more like just constantly flipping a coin and calling heads/tails than an actual survival strategy game.\nBesides that it's kinda easy to last a long time. I last around 50 days not trying to conserve
commentsCount: Some people have screenshots of 300-400 days
column16:
and one dev commented of surviving 1000+ days.  Really downplays the strategy and relies on the luck.

I say wait for three things to happen with this game:
1. Clearer tutorial/tips/knowledge. Right now no guides are really reliable
column18: the devs think this whole "experiment" idea is fun but it's really just more of a reason to not bother playing again and lamenting on the loss of 8 bucks.\n2. Less clunky.  Let them clean up the scavenge mode
column19: and hope it gets more reliable. Till then you'll probably just be miserable trying to play through it.\n3. Price decrease. I think this could be worth it for a 10 dollar game even if just one of the things above happens
column20: and if they worked out all the kinks they could even justify a 15 dollar price tag (and the selling of DLC). But as it stands currently
column21: it's more like a 5 dollar game."

reviewText: This game is just stupid. It stops the character from moving forward when a briefcase?! falls down infront of you, and it only gives you 60 seconds to grab all that you want to with a broken grab" function that allows you to grab something only once every 2 seconds. ITS TOO HARD even on the easy setting. And there is no clear cut way of completing the game at all
date: I presume the aim of the game is to survive
recommended:
but no matter how hard I try even out to 70 days I cannot survive.

Firstly. No disaster scenario ever takes into account needing only 60 seconds before a nuclear bomb falls. As a matter of fact the minuteman missles take 15 minutes to reach from Russia to the USA.

Secondly. The game is too difficult especially when a cockroach can end up killing your whole family
hoursPlayed: This game has never heard of shoes?. And you're only allowed to carry 1 maybe 2 of your family members at any one point in time. Unrealistic
voteText: don't they have legs of their own? Why can't you talk to them and get them to run around in a panic collecting resources/the kids?\n\nAnd why is there a second lag between pressing W and the charachter actually beginning to move? Isn't that a little unfair? I mean okay
helpfulPercent:
the guy is pretty fat but this is a video game!

Thirdly. No flashlight is that fragile that it couldn't survive an earthquake. No radio is that fragile that it couldn't survive a flood (unrealistic and damages the gameplay). No Map couldn't survive a flood. No book couldn't survive a flood. So why are we being penalized for it? We need those items to survive the game! And you take them away from us based upon an irrational and unrealistic scenario whereby a piece of paper or a piece of electronic gear couldn't be dried out and see if it works.

Finally. The gun explodes every single time that you try and use it
votesHelpful:
And other times it works perfectly fine for at least 4 shots. Leaving the game far too much up to chance and not strategy. This single act can mean life or death for your family.

There isn't enough realism and strategy in this game and instead we have lazy programming and lazy story writing based upon the premise that most people aren't smart enough to realize that this game is childish and woefully unrealistic to the point of it being rediculous.

It feels far too much like a game which exists only to take my money and give me no enjoyable gameplay whatsoever.

Up does not equal down. But in this case my vote does."

reviewText:
Editing review since Devs wanted more feedback....

1. Overly difficult on easiest level. Easy needs to truly be easy so people can learn the game.

2. There's such a large amount of random bad things that happen to you that it's incredibly hard to ever win. Even when you do win, it's pretty much pure luck. It's not a win because you made wise or smart choices.

3. I've posted twice about this but I keep getting pinned in by bandits on pretty much all my games. On or about day 26, on about 90% of my games, I get hit by bandits. From then on they never go away. They will constantly attack my base and will capture anyone that is sent out. Thus as soon as bandits appear, my game is effectively over. I've rode out the bandits as long as 50 days...and they still would not go away.

4. Too much junk in the way when you're trying to gather items for the shelter (in the 60 seconds). I can't tell you how many times I've had a chair/lamp/etc jam me up in a room where it took me like 20 seconds to get it out of the way. It's already hectic enough without silly random items jamming you in a corner you can't get out of.

That's just a few items off top of my head but the bandits thing is the huge one. It literally happens on 90% of my games. My normal routine in sending out scavengers is as follows:

Day 3: Timmy out as long as gas mask is available. (in truth someone is going out on day 3 no matter what)

Day 12ish: Girl or boy out when radiation is gone.

Day 20ish: Send a random person out to scavenge.

Around day 24-26 i start hearing the bandits and from then on the game is over.

It's not like im sending people out a lot.
voteText: 8 of 23 people (35%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I am not impressed!

The game lacks depth, have bad gameplay and feel like it could have been made in flash.

I like survival games. The 60s and nuclear destruction is interesting to me but I got really bored playing this game.

It starts up with a early 2000 looking 3d house were you try to grab supplies and it is not well executed. It just feels cheap. That only last like 90 seconds and then you get to play a poor text adventure were you mostly do this: Get to send one member of you family to gather supplies (the supplies gathered are random). See to the need of your family and give them either food, drink or first aid. Then have a random event that makes you choose a tool or not for a random outcome. This keeps on going until your characters die or you die from boredom.

It looks cheap, it bored me and the only way I could recommend it is if it was alot cheaper.

My recommendation is that you buy 'This war of mine'. That game has some entertainment at least.

Edit: Still can't fatom why people would give this game such high reviews, it's beyond me. Reminder: it's easy to get a steam refund these days if you don't take to long.
I guess I do not hold it against the developers but what bothers me is that the reviews DO NOT represesent the game and I am not the kind of person that goes out of my way to trash on a game.
Your input is appreciated

reviewText:
Good idea.  Execution couldn't have been poorer.

The idea of this game, survival / comedy / tragedy during a nuclear holocaust is great.  The game fails in every way to make this wonderful idea come to life.

Basically, it just wasn't built right.  There are huge FPS lag issues which shouldn't be there considering what the game mechanics are.  On the average gaming system, this game suffers.  I can't speak to a $2000 gaming setup, but I imagine that's what you'd need for something that isn't highly technical.

This was a huge disappointment and I hope someone will take the idea and do it right.

I have to disagree with any comparison to Fallout.  There is no similarity in my opinion.

reviewText:
60 Seconds is an interesting adventure in decision making. Some days you get the carrot and more often than not, you get the radioactive Commie Beating Stick. I love the aesthetics, I love the 1950's scare of nuclear war, the mad dash you need to make to get your family into the shelter, to slowly watch as the bunker drives everyone into the dirt. I love it all as a game, but my biggest draw, and unfortunately this was the thing that made me refund it, was the fact there is so little to do.

The game looks good, it sounds good and it plays well but it becomes boring just clicking the same menus after each day. I appreciate the craft made to show things both being damaged or used such as a torn gas mask, ripped up map or having Timmy wear a colander and holding a squirrel (if I remember correctly). I just don't recommend buying this for 10 dollars.

Maybe if a few minigames or a few other features were thrown in it'd be a lot more fun. But the mad dash at the beginning is the biggest core component of its gameplay. Sure you can play the tutorial, practice getting supplies & eventually running the full game and seeing where you stand. My longest streak was 40 days and when I played for the first hour, it was a lot of fun but I noticed it was very repetitive. Maybe that's part of the point, and if so, sorry I missed it.
Sending people out is about the second funnest part of the game aside from the overall decision making process. I just wish there was more control over it. More to do. I'd like to pick the place I could go maybe, maybe pick the actions I make or what supplies. The game is very text intensive, and I apprciate that, so I don't see why we couldn't have some more prompts out in the field or handling situations.

I felt bad refunding this game, because I really like the idea but $10.00 for something like this, compared to say a game like LISA, it kind of really draws points against itself for $10.00. If this game had a little more, just some more decisions, maybe a bigger house, maybe a smaller house, maybe just a few more options to really make it your own experience, with maybe a bit more gameplay elements, and I'd have kept it wholeheartedly. I'd like to maybe rename the Wife and Kids and Ted as it were. It'd make me feel more involved.
I mean I could feel their plight, being stuck somewhere for a long period is no fun. So if I missed the point, again I'm sorry but I feel like this would make a good game to give a kid in his younger ages like maybe 11 to 13 and say here have some fun with this" and it'd satisfy their desire to make decisions
recommended: it didn't hold my attention long enough combined with the price point.\n\nI'll be honest
hoursPlayed:
I'll pick it up again when it goes on sale probably because I see hope for it. I just wish I didn't have to feel like I wasn't getting my moneys worth.

Enjoyed the game? Why don't you make your own Tomato Soup?

You will need:

5 lbs tomatoes
1 tablespoon prepared horseradish
1⁄2 teaspoon mild Tabasco sauce
salt & pepper
5 ounces tomato paste

Then,

Boil water to dip tomatoes.
Wash tomatoes. Dip in boiling water 30 to 60 seconds. Immediately dip in cold water. Slip off skins. Trim away any green areas & stems.
Cut tomatoes add to crock pot and add all ingredients.
Cook on high for 4 hours.
Strain seeds and pulp out and return to crock pot.
Cook for 2 hours.
Serve with a side of rice or toasted cheese sandwitch.

reviewText:
The survival part is a lot of reading, but basic common sense goes a long way. Grabbing what is close by never seemed more vital. It does have charm to it. I love the feeling of it. It is a very fun to do the grabbing things in 60 seconds part. Makes you think about what you would grab. The different play throughs do offer a bit of variety, so each game will not be exactly the same. Yet, there are times you do encounter pretty much the same choices.

I do like the game, and sadly I have to say after playing This War of Mine, and finding the complexity of the story, this game just doesn't add up to the price they charge for it. With only one playthrough, I really hope they add more than just one scenario of apocalypse. Yes, they let you play just survival or just 60 seconds grabbing, but I do feel having different kinds of scenarios would be more fun. Sadly after only about an hour and a half of game play, I have nothing else new to play.

Overall, I can say, if you are looking to get this game, wait until it is on sale. It is definately a charming game, but seeing how others that compete against this type of gameplay, I would say they should add more. Maybe there will be an update to this review. Who knows?

reviewText:
My family but the daughter Mary-Jane, who perished in the attack, was safe since 58 days... when raiders went into my fallout shelter, tied my family up and stole everything in it. All these troubles for a bad decision of me. They had everything: water, food, weapons, a radio, a map and even some distractions. The dad went out to find some extra supplies, but he fell straight on a band of thugs. Dolores, the mother, died of deshydratation, leaving Timmy, the little boy, alone in the shelter.

60 Seconds! is a good game, a little and simple one, not a super production of some gigantic company, but it do the job. It's distracting. Sometimes captivating, sometime disappointing. But every event is the result of one of your choices. So you have to be careful, and wise. Possibilities are not infinite currently, but there's a big update incoming, and that game is already a good way to spend your time for thirty minutes/an hour per day.

I'll recommend it. 60 Seconds! is quick and effective, so for a good price, at least less than 1/4 of a current big" game

reviewText:
The game is solid. Not really my thing, and I got bored of it incredibly quickly, but I can see how people can replay this again and again.

Your house is randomized each time. You get a few seconds of grace to look around, and then the siren goes off. You have 60 seconds to grab as much as you can carry and hunker down in your fallout shelter, and then the game sorta becomes a text-based survival game. Every day, you have to ration food and water to you(And your family if you remembered to bring them along with you), and generally you'll have to face some sort of complication, such as a phone ringing on the surface, the venhilation in your shelter shutting down, or a random band of performers in green tights knocking on your door and asking to perform for you(These are all real examples of what happened to me in the couple of playthroughs I did). Additionally you'll usually be given the option to send someone onto the surface to look for supplies, but this can be a risky prospect because, as you should know, the Wasteland is a dangerous place.

Overall there seem to be a lot of random little disasters that can happen in your shelter, and if you liked games like Oregon Trail, you'll probably enjoy this little gem, too. It's a fun enough little game with a great sense of humour, and it's one of the better $10 games on Steam.

reviewText:
After watching a Lets Play of 60 Seconds" I got curious and grabbed it.

The gameplay is obvious: the first 60 seconds are spent gathering supplies and family while the rest of the game is largely RNG events. Eventually the family dies or gets saved depending largely on how the dice roll more than anything else.

The game is low-effort as far as development goes. No animations are involved after the first 60 seconds - you just stare at an unmoving image for about 20 minutes at a time. There are little changes here and there that visibly show changes in the characters' statuses as well as what items you have and what shape they're in.

For the majority of the game you're at the mercy of randomness. Even if you played an event last game it very well could be a different result if you picked a yes or no this time. The only ones that have predictable results are the events that require you to pick and use an item in the shelter - often at the cost of the item.

Would the game be better if there were more active events that went beyond reading RNG event text? I don't know. It stands out as it's own game even if it lacks for excitement or effort. It doesn't strike me personally as very entertaining
date: but it does have a charm to it."

reviewText: The games trailer tells what the game is about just not how it works out. Decision making gets repetitive as you come across the same issues at one point or a another. Its a fun game and a great concept but has some major flaws and gets repetitive after the first few times you play it. I rate the game a 5/10.

reviewText:
60 seconds! is a game about a man named Ted, who's neighborhood is unfortunately is being bombed. Not just any old bombs, lovely nuclear warheads! Now it would be just too easy to just hop in a fully stocked shelter, wouldn't it? Well, now the sirens are blazing, and you look in your shelter and realize you have got nothing in it! But not to worry, the military's new and improved, wonderful nuclear siren gives Ted enough time to grab (almost) all he needs to fill his shelter! But wait Ted, aren't you forgetting something? Your family! Your lazy family that won't help you! Your lazy family that wouldn't even care to bother that there are nukes dropping all around them! Your lazy family that won't even go in the shelter even if it was 3 steps away from them! *BOOM*

Woah there Ted, you barely made it in! Well, not to worry, you and your family is safe! Now you must survive by rationing supplies each day, and sending people out on an expedition to the outside when supplies get low! Not to worry, those cat-sized cockroaches wont do anything too bad, now would they?? Good thing you brought your bug spray, wait... you didn't?!? Well... good luck!

11/10 would kill Timmy again! (well, that sounds wrong)

My least favorite part about this whole game, is that it gets repetitive, but only for the first 10 days or so, then the random events start rolling in.
My top 6 favorite things about the game is...
1) Great art style!
2) Awesome soundtrack!
3) Many different events!
4) Has hilarious comedy involved!
5) Bombs (difficulty settings) are based off real things!
6) Has real life feel to it (don't feed = die,  no water for 4 days = death,  no gas mask/protection = sick)

This game is worth 100% of the money!

Once again...  11/10 would write another intro story!

reviewText:
I laughed for the first hour I played this game. Very entertaining in the beginning, but it turns out to be a bit repetitve once you've played through a couple of times. It seems next to impossible to get rescued. I made it 46 days with a map and a radio, and no rescue!

Anyways, this game really reminds me of Oregon Trail. Unfortunately, you can't put your buddies names in. You're stuck with the stock names. Also, I was kind of bummed they didn't add a cat or dog into it!

I'm still dabbling with the game after a few hours of use. I find it more fun to put myself in impossible scenarios and see how the characters react. I'm not sure the game is worth $15, but it was definitely a very entertaining first hour of game play. So, why not.

After about 20 hours in this game I would like to finally write this review.

The game is nothing special really and it has a pretty general setting and theme. It has a nice comedic feel and the beginning is fairly enjoyable but average at best.

Where this game primarily thrives in my opinion is the survival stage, in this stage you are meant to make choices and otherwise do whatever it takes to keep you and your family alive.

Overall this game gets a 7/10 from me, although it may be skewed slightly because of my love for the apocalyptic setting.

reviewText:
The survival part is a lot of reading, but basic common sense goes a long way. Grabbing what is close by never seemed more vital. It does have charm to it. I love the feeling of it. It is a very fun to do the grabbing things in 60 seconds part. Makes you think about what you would grab. The different play throughs do offer a bit of variety, so each game will not be exactly the same. Yet, there are times you do encounter pretty much the same choices.

I do like the game, and sadly I have to say after playing This War of Mine, and finding the complexity of the story, this game just doesn't add up to the price they charge for it. With only one playthrough, I really hope they add more than just one scenario of apocalypse. Yes, they let you play just survival or just 60 seconds grabbing, but I do feel having different kinds of scenarios would be more fun. Sadly after only about an hour and a half of game play, I have nothing else new to play.

Overall, I can say, if you are looking to get this game, wait until it is on sale. It is definately a charming game, but seeing how others that compete against this type of gameplay, I would say they should add more. Maybe there will be an update to this review. Who knows?

reviewText:
This game isn't for everyone. You need to be the kind of person who stubbornly plays games like Don't Starve and keeps hitting the new game button after being brutally killed while cursing the developers.

Trail and error are how you learn the ropes in this game and even then, you aren't	quite sure if you actually have a rope or not because it's hard to tell if you're doing the right thing, or anything at all. I think it's supposed to be like real life, you aren't sure if you're totally destroying your future by asking out a girl from OkCupid, but you're going to hit the next button just to see what happens.

It may be months before you realize you bombed that date because of your own ego or you may never learn why she stopped calling you back at all. That's pretty much this game. So much of the time you just have no idea what the results of your actions are. For example, you ration food. What happens if you give someone more food then usual? Do they get better stats? Do they go crazy slower? Who knows!

Making progress is really difficult. In fact, I'm starting to suspect the game purposely sets up hurdles by making the next event unlock through an item you don't have in your shelter or by an item that was just destroyed. The bad things that happen to your survivors don't feel random, but standard. If you have too much gear, it's going to get destroyed, period.

The dark humor goes with the game pretty well. Your children are really just radioactive conure birds and you need to start thinking of them like that to advance.  Only there aren't a ton of jokes and you'll quickly exhaust the supply of events and keep hitting the next button because you already know what's happening.

The price may be a bit steep though. I'm hoping the free DLC will fatten up the game like a gerbil with some delicious tomato soup.

First Hour of Play

reviewText:
This is a game about a 1950's family living their lives, enjoying life as it is...

Until a fallout happens.

You have 60 seconds to grab your family, along with supplies and 4 slots worth, to put them in the shelter. If you don't get into the shelter in time, you immediatly perish. You can choose to leave all of your family or collect all of them. You have 3 family members, including you, Ted. Once 60 seconds are up, you get into the shelter.

You can choose 3 modes: Little Boy, where you get longer exploration time, a hefty stocked shelter/briefcase, rare problems, and good opportunities, Fat Man, where you get average exploration time, problems, average shelter/briefcase, and decent opportinities. Then, Tsar Bomba: the hardest difficulty where you get no exploration time, no stocked shelter/briefcase, often there are problems, and no good opportunities. This gamemode is for the adept player, and for the most hardest, realistic fallout gameplay.

Once you are in the shelter, you have until you die or until you get rescued by the government. You can choose to send people out into the barren wasteland (yet full of suprises, good or bad) to scavenge for supplies and food/water. There are also sometimes where you play a game of chance: for example, an empty suitcase appears on your doorstep. There's no one around, and there's no writing on the case. Do you open it? There are a few possibilities: there could be water and food in it (ONLY water and food), it doesn't have anything in it, it could explode and hurt someone, or it could have food/water, but it makes your family sick. See what I mean? It's all about skill, gambling, and achievement.

This game is EXTREMELY worth the $10 bucks, and has extremely high replay value. All in all, this game has:
-No story, you make your OWN story
-Gambling and risks
-A dog! (you have to earn the dog)
-Desision-making and strategy
-Fallout survival

Survive as much as you can with this amazing strategic game! 9.7/10, needs just a tiny bit more time when collecting supplies.

reviewText: 60 Seconds!" Review\n60 Seconds! is a action and text-based survival game. You're in charge of overlooking a family in a fallout shelter. You have to keep the family alive long enough for the military or someone else to come and rescue you. But there are many different scenarios in which you can die. Thisis one of my favorite games I've ever played. It's simplicity is just awe-inspiring yet the artwork is great! There are thousands of different paths. The survival aspect is great but the collection mode isn't. It's controls are pretty bad and the graphics are even worse. This is an amazing game but it definitley has some flaws that need to be worked on. Still though
recommended: great and simply amazing. It's most definitley worth $10."

reviewText: An exceptionally charming little game simulating 1950's America's nuclear attack readiness practices in a brilliantly dark comic style.\nI'd compare the gameplay to that of This War Of Mine, but with much less of an emotional pull and focus on greater human empathy. Congratulations to Robot Gentlemen on such a great game!

reviewText:
Generally a pretty good game. Does feel in parts like it could have action but then it still works well as more of a strategy game. I'd say, for example, when sending people on expeditions you slightly wish you could play as the character for a while, but then not being able to kind of relates to the sense of cabin fever the characters gain over time. Also the background song is short and is repeated a lot over a long session, so many times you eventually forget about it but when you do notice it it becomes gradually more and more boring to listen to (less so than no music), so this makes me consider that it was intentional for the developers to try to help players personally feel that sense of boredom and cabin fever to a small extent.

Gameplay eventually becomes dull although given the content of the game (i.e how the family becomes mad with boredom) it seems appropriate and its a game I can go back to playing after a while.

Controls are slightly awkward, the mouse needs to be clicked slightly to the right of targets and also it feels a bit hard to control Ted during the '60 Seconds!'.

Some parts of the game just bothered me because they didn't fully seem logical. For example if Ted dies but not the others in the family you cannot just carry on playing with the other survivors. This doesn't really fit in with the rest of the game as you aren't exactly playing as Ted (although it could be interpreted as him being the leader of the family and you making decisions on his behalf a lot of the time), save for during the minute at the start. Also the game encourages players to protect each person in the family equally which kind of contradicts that its really about protecting Ted.

Overall, not the most thrilling game ever but interesting strategy, some pretty sharp satire and good quality for a cheap game. Worth the money, and generally pretty fun as strategy games can sometimes be slightly dull just making decisions whereas this has some humour in it as well as the main gameplay. I've probably said more about flaws I found in the game but that's mainly because its easier to point out flaws in something as they seem to stand out more.

reviewText:
My family but the daughter Mary-Jane, who perished in the attack, was safe since 58 days... when raiders went into my fallout shelter, tied my family up and stole everything in it. All these troubles for a bad decision of me. They had everything: water, food, weapons, a radio, a map and even some distractions. The dad went out to find some extra supplies, but he fell straight on a band of thugs. Dolores, the mother, died of deshydratation, leaving Timmy, the little boy, alone in the shelter.

60 Seconds! is a good game, a little and simple one, not a super production of some gigantic company, but it do the job. It's distracting. Sometimes captivating, sometime disappointing. But every event is the result of one of your choices. So you have to be careful, and wise. Possibilities are not infinite currently, but there's a big update incoming, and that game is already a good way to spend your time for thirty minutes/an hour per day.

I'll recommend it. 60 Seconds! is quick and effective, so for a good price, at least less than 1/4 of a current big" game

reviewText:
Its a very fun and intense game, of course it might be a bit repetetive if you play it long enough, but overall I think i'ts good. Basically there's this nuclear explosion that happens, and you have 60 seconds to gather your family and as much supplies as you can, and then try to survive as long as you can in your bunker until the military rescues you.

Afcourse you also have to send people out to scavenge ocassionaly. Especially when you're low on supplies, there will be different types of events such as bandits trying to raid you, dealing with cockroaches, and animals or creatures trying to steal your food. For that you will need different items to deal with those problems.

And that's about it. I rate the game 6.5/10

reviewText:
WARNING: OSX USERS - THIS GAME HAS ISSUES

I really wanted to play this game.  I purchased it on 27 November 15.   My Mac exceeds the requirements.

The intro and main menu load fine; however, once you click to begin the game will turn black and freeze.

This appears to be a problem since October.  It has *not* been fixed.  Check the discussions page before purchasing, there's a thread about OSX and another one about black screens.  There's a post as recent as 28 December, showng the problem has not been fixed.  You'll note there have been no patches or working solutions given.

A shame, because it looks like it might be fun.

I returned the game.  Save yourself the hassle and don't buy it in its current stage.

reviewText: Man, I want to like this game.  There is something to the second half of the survival part.  But the first part in 3D still needs a lot of work.  The controls are infuriatingly bad.  Floaty controls and don't respond when you press a button.  I get there's maybe something to simulating panic but if I do a bad run picking up stuff I never feel like it's because I did bad. Because I'm sitting there jamming on the grab button and nothing is happening.\n\nIf the controls got overhauled there or changed to a 2D thing or something, this game would start out a whole lot better.  Right now though I find myself re-starting like 20 times before playing because I feel like the first run was bull ♥♥♥♥ because of the controls and I think I can do better.

reviewText: Fun premise, but the frustrating controls, bugs, severe lag, and otherwise poor UI ruins the 60 second scavenge run that the game is supposed to be built around. The bulk of the game is spent on a mostly static image of the bunker where you ration supplies and make choices for random events that occur each day. This is entirely text based. If you loathe random number generators, then pack your bag full of soup cans and run for the hills. The game is briming with humor, however, the jokes will become repetitive as you will likely encounter the same events on each playthrough. If you can look past the clunky initial 3D portion of the game, you might find the choose-your-own-adventure style game amusing the first few playthroughs, but the replay value will likely diminish steeply. Worth buying if the developers optimize the game and the price drops to around $5.

reviewText:
Enjoyed the game? Why don't you make your own Tomato Soup?

You will need:

5 lbs tomatoes
1 tablespoon prepared horseradish
1⁄2 teaspoon mild Tabasco sauce
salt & pepper
5 ounces tomato paste

Then,

Boil water to dip tomatoes.
Wash tomatoes. Dip in boiling water 30 to 60 seconds. Immediately dip in cold water. Slip off skins. Trim away any green areas & stems.
Cut tomatoes add to crock pot and add all ingredients.
Cook on high for 4 hours.
Strain seeds and pulp out and return to crock pot.
Cook for 2 hours.
Serve with a side of rice or toasted cheese sandwitch.

reviewText:
Fun game of random events & choices where you learn about sacrifice. Like when you stop saving your fat daughter on playthroughs because she takes up 3 slots.

On my last playthrough I only saved my son, chose supplies over family.
Days later, sounds of knocking on my shelter.
Much to my surprise, my wife survived the blast. She was now crazy.
I couldn't handle her so I left her alone with my son while I went scavenging.
By the time I returned, she broke the radio & drove our son crazy as well.
Ringing phone outside was going to drove me crazy so I sent my son to answer.
I hoped he'd never return, but he did.
Then I sent him on a scavenging hunt by himself. He never returned. Thank god.
Now childless, alone with wife, she drove me insane like she did our only son.
Now both crazy, me wearing a sock on my hand, we became risk takers.
We bonded by attacking old folks & killing bugs. I remembered why I married her.
My wife & I died together on day 28. A true romance story.
Next time, I'll save her & let the kids die.

Dumb fun.

8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
This is a game about a 1950's family living their lives, enjoying life as it is...

Until a fallout happens.

You have 60 seconds to grab your family, along with supplies and 4 slots worth, to put them in the shelter. If you don't get into the shelter in time, you immediatly perish. You can choose to leave all of your family or collect all of them. You have 3 family members, including you, Ted. Once 60 seconds are up, you get into the shelter.

You can choose 3 modes: Little Boy, where you get longer exploration time, a hefty stocked shelter/briefcase, rare problems, and good opportunities, Fat Man, where you get average exploration time, problems, average shelter/briefcase, and decent opportinities. Then, Tsar Bomba: the hardest difficulty where you get no exploration time, no stocked shelter/briefcase, often there are problems, and no good opportunities. This gamemode is for the adept player, and for the most hardest, realistic fallout gameplay.

Once you are in the shelter, you have until you die or until you get rescued by the government. You can choose to send people out into the barren wasteland (yet full of suprises, good or bad) to scavenge for supplies and food/water. There are also sometimes where you play a game of chance: for example, an empty suitcase appears on your doorstep. There's no one around, and there's no writing on the case. Do you open it? There are a few possibilities: there could be water and food in it (ONLY water and food), it doesn't have anything in it, it could explode and hurt someone, or it could have food/water, but it makes your family sick. See what I mean? It's all about skill, gambling, and achievement.

This game is EXTREMELY worth the $10 bucks, and has extremely high replay value. All in all, this game has:
-No story, you make your OWN story
-Gambling and risks
-A dog! (you have to earn the dog)
-Desision-making and strategy
-Fallout survival

Survive as much as you can with this amazing strategic game! 9.7/10, needs just a tiny bit more time when collecting supplies.

reviewText:
60 Seconds is an interesting adventure in decision making. Some days you get the carrot and more often than not, you get the radioactive Commie Beating Stick. I love the aesthetics, I love the 1950's scare of nuclear war, the mad dash you need to make to get your family into the shelter, to slowly watch as the bunker drives everyone into the dirt. I love it all as a game, but my biggest draw, and unfortunately this was the thing that made me refund it, was the fact there is so little to do.

The game looks good, it sounds good and it plays well but it becomes boring just clicking the same menus after each day. I appreciate the craft made to show things both being damaged or used such as a torn gas mask, ripped up map or having Timmy wear a colander and holding a squirrel (if I remember correctly). I just don't recommend buying this for 10 dollars.

Maybe if a few minigames or a few other features were thrown in it'd be a lot more fun. But the mad dash at the beginning is the biggest core component of its gameplay. Sure you can play the tutorial, practice getting supplies & eventually running the full game and seeing where you stand. My longest streak was 40 days and when I played for the first hour, it was a lot of fun but I noticed it was very repetitive. Maybe that's part of the point, and if so, sorry I missed it.
Sending people out is about the second funnest part of the game aside from the overall decision making process. I just wish there was more control over it. More to do. I'd like to pick the place I could go maybe, maybe pick the actions I make or what supplies. The game is very text intensive, and I apprciate that, so I don't see why we couldn't have some more prompts out in the field or handling situations.

I felt bad refunding this game, because I really like the idea but $10.00 for something like this, compared to say a game like LISA, it kind of really draws points against itself for $10.00. If this game had a little more, just some more decisions, maybe a bigger house, maybe a smaller house, maybe just a few more options to really make it your own experience, with maybe a bit more gameplay elements, and I'd have kept it wholeheartedly. I'd like to maybe rename the Wife and Kids and Ted as it were. It'd make me feel more involved.
I mean I could feel their plight, being stuck somewhere for a long period is no fun. So if I missed the point, again I'm sorry but I feel like this would make a good game to give a kid in his younger ages like maybe 11 to 13 and say here have some fun with this" and it'd satisfy their desire to make decisions
recommended: it didn't hold my attention long enough combined with the price point.\n\nI'll be honest
hoursPlayed:
I'll pick it up again when it goes on sale probably because I see hope for it. I just wish I didn't have to feel like I wasn't getting my moneys worth.

The design? Good.
The sound?  Satisfying.
Gameplay? Lacking
voteText: my biggest point against it.\nI hope this game grows and the people who made it continue to add to it
helpfulPercent: but as it stands I don't recommend it for the combined price point and lack of overall variety"

reviewText:
This game is fun, and some sort of strategy is a must. If you always end up dieing due to lack of supplies or any other reason, here's a guide to sure survival:


1. Always wait five days for feeding. They can only survive without water for that long, and without soup for 7 days. But to keep it easier on your mind, just do both every 5 days.


2. just bring dolores with you. It decreases the drain on supplies and you can still win even if ted dies. But ted MUST get to the shelter before the timer runs out for you to actually start the surviving.


3. ALWAYS try to get the ammo, bugspray, scout book, med kit, the suitcase, the flashlight (torch) and radio. The ammo helps you with the showering problem (You'll know what it is when you see it). The bugspray helps you repair the med kit, but you need the med kit first for it to be an option. The scout book lets you repair anything that can be broken in the game. The med kit, well, you know why. The suitcase can have good items inside and opens the other three hands in the scavenging equipment" page. The flaslight help's you get Pancake
date: which is the dog. You'll  know when Pancake appears when it says something about "Glowing eyes in the dark" and lets you choose one of the following: The bugspray
hoursPlayed: or the flashlight in that order with the flashlight at the right of the page. The radio let's you get the military ending

reviewText:
This game is a fantastic little romp through a post-nuclear wasteland; figuratively speaking of course, given the fact that the game, following a rather clumsy 60 second mad-dash to the shelter, grabbing everything you can, is spent underground. For the most part, all interaction with the wastes above is done through text. If you love the dark brand of humour that Fallout brought to the table, you'll love this game.

Whilst I love the game in it's current form, I feel there's quite simply not enough to keep you busy really. A few more levels akin to the 60 seconds rush to safety at the beginning, say, digging around in the ruins of your neighbour's homes for ammunition, water and the oh-so-precious, gift from the gods of this game; soup.

Be prepared for the future; or don't, and end up regretting it as your family die around you!

9.6/10

reviewText:
After watching a Lets Play of 60 Seconds" I got curious and grabbed it.

The gameplay is obvious: the first 60 seconds are spent gathering supplies and family while the rest of the game is largely RNG events. Eventually the family dies or gets saved depending largely on how the dice roll more than anything else.

The game is low-effort as far as development goes. No animations are involved after the first 60 seconds - you just stare at an unmoving image for about 20 minutes at a time. There are little changes here and there that visibly show changes in the characters' statuses as well as what items you have and what shape they're in.

For the majority of the game you're at the mercy of randomness. Even if you played an event last game it very well could be a different result if you picked a yes or no this time. The only ones that have predictable results are the events that require you to pick and use an item in the shelter - often at the cost of the item.

Would the game be better if there were more active events that went beyond reading RNG event text? I don't know. It stands out as it's own game even if it lacks for excitement or effort. It doesn't strike me personally as very entertaining
date: but it does have a charm to it."

1. Always wait five days for feeding. They can only survive without water for that long, and without soup for 7 days. But to keep it easier on your mind, just do both every 5 days.


2. just bring dolores with you. It decreases the drain on supplies and you can still win even if ted dies. But ted MUST get to the shelter before the timer runs out for you to actually start the surviving.


3. ALWAYS try to get the ammo, bugspray, scout book, med kit, the suitcase, the flashlight (torch) and radio. The ammo helps you with the showering problem (You'll know what it is when you see it). The bugspray helps you repair the med kit, but you need the med kit first for it to be an option. The scout book lets you repair anything that can be broken in the game. The med kit, well, you know why. The suitcase can have good items inside and opens the other three hands in the scavenging equipment" page. The flaslight help's you get Pancake
date: which is the dog. You'll  know when Pancake appears when it says something about "Glowing eyes in the dark" and lets you choose one of the following: The bugspray
hoursPlayed: or the flashlight in that order with the flashlight at the right of the page. The radio let's you get the military ending
voteText:
which I got. Don't believe me? check my profile and one of my pictures show military soldiers in the shelter with ted and dolores.


I hope this was useful

reviewText:
Dammit if I am not a huge Markiplier fan... he is to blame for the time lost (and more to come) to this addictive slice of hellish must beat and get every achievement game. Damn you Markilplier!!! Seriously though, I have a very love hate relationship with this game which is why I keep playing it. I am a huge fan of the simple forms of entertainment and this game provides hours of randomness and I have yet to be rescued!!! The one time I felt like I had every necessary item and plenty of food and water the whole family went crazy on day 3 with no warning signs?!?! I couldn't go on expeditions until one day Ted was suddenly not crazy anymore, but by that time I had run out of water. The last game, let's just say good things happen when you don't kill the spiders but again, I eventually ran out of water..... water is very important.

But I love this game!!!! If you must beat every game or get every achievement then you should probably not get this game unless you have many many hours to play it. If the latter is true, get the game, strap in and try to live through the nuclear wastelands.

If you don't know who Markiplier is..... you aren't a true gamer and shame on you!!!!

reviewText:
60 Seconds is an enjoyable, quirky little game about surviving after the end of the world. The game is split into two main elements, a pre-apocalypse scramble for supplies and the actual surviving after the bombs have dropped, the scramble does add a lot of tension to the game and players will be forced to prioritize certain supplies such as Water and Food over luxuries like a pack of cards or a magazine, but pretty much every supply can be used in some way whilst surviving and not picking up that pack of cards or can of bug spray may lead to surprising events. The game also has a mode that lets you simply see how long you can survive using a set amount of supplies without the scramble part as well.


I personally played this game after watching it being played on Youtube, and found myself drawn to it's choose-your-own adventure style gameplay, perhaps not the best description for the games actual genre, but I feel it's fits.

The game overall is sometimes based on luck as well, will you find the supplies you need, will someone get sick or need more water than usual, will a mutant cockroach appear and infect someone, you don't know and that can be little annoying at times, but most playthroughs of the game are fast, before you inevitably end up dying or going crazy, which does help to alleviate the frustration factor.

If you fancy seeing how far you can make it through the game or just find it interesting to look at, I highly recommend playing this game.

reviewText: Short, but fun.\nDefinitely worth the money spent for the game. I hope there will be future updates adding even more to the game. I don't really get to do the minigame in the beginning since it's too slow for my computer, but I'm glad they added survival for those of us who can't. I enjoy the style of the game, and the humor is hilariously morbid. I wouldn't reccomend this for people who are more action oriented as it falls more under the strategy category. It's just right for me however, as I love being able to think out how to ration my resources and play through it.
